questions.text: Non-shivering thermogenesis is classically defined as a cold-induced increase in heat production not associated with shivering activity. This Non-shivering thermogenesis in adults is due to?
questions.solution: Nonshivering thermogenesis was originally defined as a cold-induced increase in heat production not associated with the muscle activity of shivering. Recent research shows it to be a metabolic process located primarily in brown adipose tissue and controlled by the activity of the sympathetic nervous supply of this tissue. Another stimulus to sympathetic nervous activity, the ingestion of inferior and lateral in the territory of the food, promotes diet-induced thermogenesis middle cerebral artery, whereas the lower in brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: The peripheral blood smear of an anemic 1-year-old child is shown in the illustration. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The peripheral blood film shows anisocytosis (different size of red cells) and poikilocytosis (different shapes). Red cells are microcytic hypochromic. Pencil cells are seen.
    • Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of hypochromic microcytic anemia.

questions.text: A 25-year old woman brings her 1-year-old daughter to the paediatrician. She has demonstrated a progressive series of behaviours over the first year of life. Her motor skills have diminished and she demonstrates an increased startle reaction. Physical examination is notable only for the ocular findings shown in the image. Deficiency of which of the following enzyme is responsible for this disease?
questions.solution:
Tay-Sachs disease:

  • It results from a deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme activity.
  • It is an inherited disease with an autosomal recessive trait.
  • Findings include loss of motor skills, increased startle reaction, macular pallor, and a cherry-red spot on the macula (as shown in the image).
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by the quantification of hexosaminidase levels in isolated WBCs in the blood.
  • Future at-risk pregnancies can be monitored via prenatal diagnosis by either amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling

questions.text: A woman presents for the first time at 26 weeks pregnancy. An ultrasound done reveals anencephaly. AFI is 26cm. All of the following are possible mechanisms for increased liquor in this patient, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
• Anencephaly is a lethal NTD characterized by the absence of the brain and cranium above the base of the skull and orbits.
  • It can be diagnosed as early as the first trimester on USG.
  • Polyhydramnios is commonly seen due to the following reasons:
    • Transudation of fluid across the membranes
    • The absence of swallowing
    • Absent fetal pituitary (absence of ADH hormone implies that the baby passes more urine).

questions.text: A muscle cell has an extracellular [Na+] of 140 mM and an intracellular [Na+] of 14 mM. Assuming that 2.3 RT/F = 60 mV. The muscle cell membrane is permeable to Na only. What will the membrane potential ?
questions.solution:
Nernst equation

  • Used to calculate the equilibrium potential for a single ion.
  • Mostly in applying the Nernst equation, it is assumed that the membrane is freely permeable to that ion alone.
  • ENa+ = 2.3 RT/zF log Ce/Ci
  • ENa+ = 60 mV log 140/14 = 60 mV log 10
  • ENa+= 60 mV.
  • Notice that the signs were ignored and that the higher concentration was simply placed in the numerator to simplify the log calculation.
  • To determine whether ENa+ is +60 mV or −60 mV,→ Use the intuitive approach⇒ Na+ will diffuse from extracellular to intracellular fluid down its concentration gradient, making the cell interior positive.

questions.text: A 28 yrs old, female with a previous history of nephrolithiasis was advised to do CT scan. On workup, the characteristic 'paintbrush appearance' is seen as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the common symptom in this condition?
questions.solution:
Medullary sponge disease, also known as Lenarduzzi kidney or Cacchi and Ricci disease, is a benign congenital condition generally detected incidentally during evaluation of renal colic.

ASSOCIATION -It may be associated with several congenital abnormalities, such as hemihypertrophy, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome, or Ehlers–Danlos syndrome

Essentials of Diagnosis

  • Precalyceal tubular ectasia with a pathognomonic “paintbrush appearance” on excretory urogram.
  • Usually without a positive family history and with normal renal clearance.

Clinical Findings

A. Symptoms and SignsPatients with medullary sponge disease remain asymptomatic, but some may present with nephrolithiasis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and microhematuria. Calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate stones are characteristic. Potential risk factor for stone

  1. Tubular dilation,
  2. Urinary stasis,
  3. Hypercalciuria,
  4. Hypocitraturia

B. Laboratory Findings

  1. Renal pathology Macroscopically, kidneys are of normal size with papillary deformity and calcifications. Microscopically, calcified ectatic or cystic dilations of the medullary collecting ducts are present.
  2. Urinary abnormalities Microscopic hematuria, high urine pH, hypercalciuria, and hypocitraturia are common urinary abnormalities in these patients.

C. Imaging StudiesExcretory urography in patients with medullary sponge disease shows linear striated densities in one or more papillae resembling a “paintbrush,” which is pathognomonic of this disease.

Treatment

Nephrolithiasis is treated as the one that occurs in sporadic renal stone patients. Antimicrobial therapy for a long period of time may be required to treat the urinary tract infections

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman underwent a hysterectomy for abnormal menstrual bleeding with a pelvic mass. The image of the gross specimen removed during surgery is given below. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a gross hysterectomy specimen showing multiple fibroids/ leiomyomas. This can present as abnormal uterine bleeding (usually menorrhagia) and pelvic mass.
  • Recognition is based on a solid, well defined lesion, inside a pseudocapsule, without any surrounding invasion, with a whorling pattern, which differentiates it from a malignancy and adenomyosis.

TSE TSE fly-cause sleeping sickness

questions.text: A patient with acute liver failure who is unresponsive to voice or pain stimulus is brought to ER. You're the attending intern for this case. Which one of the following is not advocated in the management for this patient?

choices.text: If tests for blood in stool are positive then give colonic washout

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is a case ofGRADE IV Hepatic encephalopathy.

Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy

  1. In the setting of acute gastrointestinal bleeding, blood in the bowel should be promptly evacuated with laxatives (and enemas if necessary) in order to reduce the nitrogen load.
  2. Hydration and correction of electrolyte imbalance
  3. No role of protein restriction component of the treatment of HE. Subsequent work has suggested that limiting protein-calorie intake is not beneficial in patients with HE.
  4. Ammonia absorption can be decreased by the administration of lactulose, a non-absorbable disaccharide that acts as an osmotic laxative
  5. Zinc supplementation is sometimes helpful

questions.text: A child of age 9 is presented in the hospital with symptoms of loss of muscle tone, speaking and learning difficulties, and marked dementia. MRI was recommended. Degeneration of which of the following structure can be seen in MRI?
questions.solution:
ANSWER OPTION C: Sylvian Fissure

  • The Sylvian fissure is the most consistent and distinct landmark of the lateral hemispheric surface of the brain.

  • It is formed by the anatomical relationship between the frontoparietal operculum, the temporal operculum, and the insula.

  • Equally important, the Sylvian fissure provides the sole passageway for the middle cerebral artery (MCA) as it courses from its origin at the bifurcation of the internal carotid artery and branches to bring blood to the entire lateral brain.

  • Damage above the Sylvian fissure in the parietal and frontal lobes tended to cause speech production deficits; damage below the Sylvian fissure in the temporal lobe tended to cause speech recognition deficits.

  • The cause of these diseases is not completely understood, and currently, there is no cure. Dementia is a collective term for several degenerative brain diseases, including Alzheimer's disease.

Option A: Cerebellum

  • Cerebellar degeneration refers to the deterioration of neurons (nerve cells) in the cerebellum (the area of the brain that controls muscle coordination and balance).

  • Conditions that cause Cerebellar degeneration may also affect other areas of the central nervous system, such as the spinal cord, the cerebral cortex (the thin layer of cells covering the brain), and the brain stem.

  • Signs and symptoms of Cerebellar degeneration may include a wide-based, uncoordinated walk; a back-and-forth tremor in the trunk of the body; uncoordinated movements of the arms and legs; slow and slurred speech; and nystagmus.

  • Cerebellar degeneration can be caused by a variety of factors, including inherited gene changes, chronic alcohol abuse, and paraneoplastic disorders.

  • An imaging exam may show that your cerebellum has grown smaller or deteriorated. These tests can also detect other brain conditions, such as a brain tumor or evidence of stroke.

Option B: Frontotemporal lobe

  • Frontotemporal disorders (FTD), sometimes called frontotemporal dementia, are the result of damage to neurons in the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain.

  • Many possible symptoms can result, including unusual behaviors, emotional problems, trouble communicating, difficulty with work, or difficulty with walking.

  • Symptoms of frontotemporal dementia:

    • Language problems – speaking slowly, struggling to make the right sounds when saying a word, getting words in the wrong order, or using words incorrectly.

    • Problems with mental abilities – getting distracted easily, struggling with planning and organization.

  • Frontotemporal degeneration is caused by progressive damage and loss of nerve cells in the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain.

  • In most people, this is accompanied by a buildup of one or the other of two proteins, tau or TDP-43.

Option D: Inferior sulcus

  • The inferior frontal sulcus is one of the major sulci of the frontal lobe, separating the middle frontal gyrus superiorly from the inferior frontal gyrus inferiorly.

  • It runs posteriorly from the frontal pole, parallel to the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure), and back to the precentral sulcus.

  • The inferior frontal sulcus is conceptualized as the landmark delineating ventro-from dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

  • Functional imaging studies report activations within the sulcus during tasks addressing cognitive control and verbal working memory, while their microstructural correlates are not well defined.

  • Symptoms:

    • Loss of movement, either partial (paresis) or complete (paralysis), on the opposite side of the body.

    • Difficulty performing tasks that require a sequence of movements.

    • The trouble with speech or language (aphasia)

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presented with a left-sided anterior neck swelling of about a week duration. It was painful and had progressively increased in size. There was accompanying dysphagia. Though fever was absent at presentation, it was later noticed on the second day of admission. Had a h/o being treated for URTI in a private clinic before 1 week. There was no hoarseness, difficulty with breathing or features suggestive of hyper-/hypothyroidism. All of the following statements are correct about the given condition except:

choices.text: Most common cause is presence of pyriform sinus

questions.solution:
Acute suppurative thyroiditis

  • Suppurative infection of thyroid
  • MC organism - staph aureus and streptococci
  • MC in children because of persistent Pyriform sinus (connection between oropharynx and thyroid)
  • Preceded by otitis media and URTI
  • Thyroid is resistant to infection ??" Because of
    • Rich vascular and lymphatic supply
    • High iodide content
    • Fibrous capsule

Clinical features

  • Pain and tenderness over thyroid - Fever, chills and rigor - Severe neck pain radiating to jaw or ear Lab investigation
  • ESR
  • WBC count

Diagnosis

  • FNAC - Presence of neutrophils
  • Culture and sensitivity - Organism and antibiotic sensitivity

Treatment

  • Incision and drainage + antibiotics
  • Recurrence: rule out pyriform sinus by barium swallow (if present, then excision should be done)

questions.text: A healthy, 26-year-old woman, recently married, is anxious to conceive and visits the physician for evaluation. She is worried that her cycles come at intervals of 28 to 32 days and not on a fixed date every month. Her clinician reassures that such variation may be normal. Which of the following about physiology of the menstrual cycle is INCORRECT?

choices.text: Ovulation follows 36 hours after the onset of LH surge
Withdrawal of endogenous progesterone results in endometrial breakdown and subsequent menstruation

questions.solution:
Menstrual cycle

  • Follicular phase is variable. Luteal phase is constant
  • FSH levels rise during ovulation
  • Ovulation follows 36 hours after the onset of LH surge or 10-12 hours after LH peak
  • Withdrawal of endogenous progesterone results in endometrial breakdown and subsequent menstruation
  • Average cycle length is 21–35 days

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy, while riding a bicycle was hit by a four-wheeler and suffered generalized abrasions over both lower limbs, rushed to a nearby hospital Inj Tetanus toxoid was administered and wound cleaning and dressing done. All of the following are false regarding the given Pathology except?

choices.text: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage.
Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules.
Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage.
In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury.

questions.solution:
• Several mechanisms are responsible for the increased permeability of postcapillary venules, a hallmark of acute inflammation.
    • Chemical mediators such as histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, elicit endothelial cell contraction which is the immediate transient response.
    • This results in increased inter-endothelial spaces - the most common mechanism of vascular leakage.
    • In most instances, leakage starts immediately after injury and is sustained for several hours until the damaged vessels are thrombosed or repaired.
    • Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cell, called transcytosis, also contributes to vascular leakage.

questions.solution:
Remember RP associations by mnemonicLUCHR.

  • Lawrence-Moon-Beidel Syndrome
  • Usher Syndrome
  • Cockayne Syndrome
  • Hallgren Syndrome
  • Refsum Syndrome

Other associations:NARP, Abetalipoproteinemia

RetinitisPigmentosa is not associated with HallervordenSpatz Syndrome

questions.text: 56-year-old Female complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 1 month, associated with pain. She added that her last menstruation was 10 years back. On Per Vaginal examination, Non-Bloody vaginal discharge was noted & the patient was irritable and anxious during examination. Endometrial biopsy was taken in OPD which revealed atypical cells. All of the following statements are true regarding the pathology described here, except?

choices.text: Seen in cells capable of dividing (labile cells)
There is an increase in the number of cells
Pathological hyperplasia can be a risk factor for malignancy
Bone marrow hyperplasia is not seen in response to peripheral blood cytopenia

questions.solution:
• Here in this given clinical scenario, patient has the symptoms of Abnormal uterine bleeding like Dysmenorrhea (pain during menses), Non bloody vaginal discharge, Pain during vaginal examination (irritable & anxious).
  • Biopsy also revealed Atypical cells which indicates Hyperplasia (precancerous condition of Endometrium).

Hyperplasia

  • Takes place if the tissue contains cells are capable of dividing.
  • Defined as an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue in response to a stimulus.

Pathologic hyperplasia

  • Most forms of pathologic hyperplasia are caused by excessive or inappropriate actions of hormones or growth factors acting on target cells.
  • Pathologic hyperplasia may eventually lead to cancerous proliferations.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of abnormal hormone-induced hyperplasia and patients with endometrial hyperplasia are at increased risk for developing endometrial cancer.
  • Bone marrow can undergo rapid hyperplasia in response to a deficiency of terminally differentiated/mature blood cells (anemia, leukopenia and/or thrombocytopenia).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman undergoes routine colonoscopy. A 2-cm submucosal nodule is identified in the appendix. Biopsy of the nodule shows nests of cells with round, uniform nuclei. Electron microscopy reveals numerous neuroendocrine granules in the cytoplasm. This patient’s neoplastic disease is associated with which of the following clinical features?
questions.solution:
• Patient is having carcinoid syndrome
  • Carcinoid syndrome is a systemic paraneoplastic disease caused by the release of hormones from carcinoid tumors (via neuroendocrine granules) into venous blood.
  • M/c site: GIT > Bronchus
  • Symptoms:
    • Flushing
    • Bronchial wheezing
    • Watery diarrhoea
    • Abdominal colic are caused by the release of serotonin, bradykinin, and histamine.
  • Histology: nests of cells with round, uniform nuclei
  • Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors:
    • Neuron-specific enolase
    • Synaptophysin
    • Chromogranin A
    • Leu 7
    • The other choices are not associated with this paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text: A 38-year-old Bengali man presents with complaints of multiple papular lesions over the body especially involving the palms and soles. The lesions are not painful. He has pigmentation of skin over the abdomen. He also has vertical white ridges over the nails. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute arsenic poisoning
    • Necrosis of intestinal mucosa with hemorrhagic gastroenteritis,
    • Hypotension,
    • Delayed cardiomyopathy,
    • Acute tubular necrosis,
    • Hemolysis.
    • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, delirium, coma, seizures;
    • Garlicky odor on breath;
    • Hyperkeratosis, hyperpigmentation, exfoliative dermatitis,
    • Mees’ lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails)
    • Sensory and motor polyneuritis, distal weakness.
  • EPIDERMODYSPLASIA VERRUCIFORMIS:
    • The lesions resemble flat warts or macules similar to those of pityriasis Versicolor. In patients with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, squamous cell cancers develop frequently at sites infected with specific HPV types, including 5 and 8.
  • LICHEN PLANUS
    • Lichen planus (LP) is a papulosquamous disorder in which the primary lesions are pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules.
  • XERODERMA PIGMENTOSUM (XP)
    • An autosomal recessive disorder Characterized by variably deficient repair of UV-induced photoproducts.
    • Their skin phenotype often manifests the dry, leathery appearance of prematurely photoaged skin as well as basal cell and squamous cell carcinomas and melanoma in the first two decades of life.

  • Limited to foot&calfQ

questions.text: An 82-year-old grandmother slipped on the washroom floor and was transported to the emergency department and admitted for examination with a complaint of great pain in her right lower limb. During physical examination it is observed by the resident that the right lower limb is laterally rotated and noticeably shorter than her left limb. Radiographic examination reveals an intracapsular fracture of the femoral neck. Which of the following arteries supplies the head of the femur in early childhood but no longer in a patient of this age?

choices.text: A branch of the obturator artery

questions.solution: The obturator artery provides the artery within the ligament of the head of the femur (in about 60%), the artery that supplies the head of the femur, primarily during childhood, later becoming atretic. In the adult this artery supplies only the area of the fovea of the head of the femur. The ligament of the head of the femur arises from the acetabular notch, there after receiving the little artery. In some individuals the medial circumflex femoral gives origin to the artery of the head. In the adult the arterial supply of the neck and head is provided by intracapsular branches of the medial circumflex femoral and lateral circumflex femoral arteries that pierce the neck of the femur, with some supply also from the gluteal arteries. The lateral circumflex femoral artery arises from the deep femoral and supplies the vastus lateralis. The pudendal artery arises from the internal iliac and provides blood supply for the structures of the perineum. Quite often, when an older patient with osteoporosis has a hip fracture, the femoral neck may have broken, precipitating a fall, rather than the fall resulting in the hip fracture.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent nasal bleeds. On examination, a pink coloured mass covered by mucosa is seen. Which of the following should not be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Juvenile angiofibroma (JA) is a unique tumor presenting almost exclusively in adolescent males.

It is a vascular tumor and most commonly supplied by the sphenopalatine artery. Therefore, Biopsy is contraindicated since it might precipitate bleeding.

The tumor usually arises from the lateral wall of the posterior nasal cavity close to the sphenopalatine foramen and the pterygoid base.

Due to this location nasal obstruction and nasal bleeding may be symptoms presented by the adolescents. Although the tumor is histopathologically classified as a benign lesion, bony erosions of the pterygoid, the clivus and the sphenoid sinus floor are common hallmarks of JAs.

Holman miller sign- Anterior bowing of the posterior maxillary wall

JNAF is best treated by surgical excision.

It is locally invasive invading the cheek, orbit, brain, nose

Tumour grows into the nasal cavity, nasopharynx and into pterygopalatine fossa, running behind the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus which is pushed forward as tumor grows.

Laterally it extends into the pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.

Most common age group- Adolescents males(Androgen dependent tumor

Patients with advanced and/recurrent JNA thought not to be amenable to complete resection with acceptable morbidity are ones treated with Radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a solitary discrete, freely movable, firm, rubbery, non-tender, well-circumscribed breast lesion. On resection biopsy, the lesion appears similar to that shown in the figure. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Fibroadenoma

  • Benign tumor
  • Presenting as a single discrete, freely movable lesion
  • Demonstrating a pattern of compressed glands and young fibrous stroma similar to that shown in the illustration.
  • Fibroadenoma is the most frequent cause of a palpable mass in the breast in women younger than 25 years of age.
  • The tumors are well-circumscribed, rubbery, grayish white nodules that bulge above the surrounding tissue and often contain slit-like spaces lined by epithelium.

questions.text: A 56 year male patient presented to the clinic with complaints of hoarseness of voice, throat pain, dysphagia and pain in the ear. Visualization of larynx was done using fibreoptic laryngoscopy which revealed Stage T3 supraglottic laryngeal cancer. Total laryngectomy was selected as a treatment option and the patient was admitted for preoperative evaluation. How do you describe Stage T3 of supraglottic laryngeal cancer?

choices.text: Tumour limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility
Tumour invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx
Tumour limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion
Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

questions.solution:
Tumor staging of Ca Larynx as per AJCC:

Definition of TNM
Primary Tumor (T)
TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed
TO No evidence of primary tumor
Tis Carcinoma in situ
Supra glottis
T1 Tumor limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord ability
T2 Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsite of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g., mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall or pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx
T3 Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space, or minor thyroid cartilage erosion (e.g., inner cortex)
T4a Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. tracha, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus)
T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastina I structures
Glottis
T1 Tumor limited to the vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissure) with normal mobility
T1a Tumor limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumor involves both vocal cords
T2 Tumor extends to supraglottis or subglottis, or with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumor limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation or invades paraglottic space, or minor thyroid cartilage erosion (e.g., inner cortex)
T4a Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage or invades tissues beyond the larynx (te.g, trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus)
T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastinal structures

questions.text: A female infant was born at 39+ weeks gestation by emergency cesarian section following a failed forceps delivery. Her mother was a primigravida and her pregnancy was uneventful. There was marked fetal distress and a cord prolapse during a forceps delivery. She was eventually delivered by the cesarian section. Apgar scores were 2 at 1min and 5 at 5min. The infant was ventilated for 12h. She developed convulsions at 18h and was reventilated until day 4. Also developed spastic quadriplegia with extensor posturing and severe microcephaly. The MRI had the following findings shown in the given image. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows abnormal signal intensity throughout the thalami, the putamen, and the globus pallidum. There is a low signal intensity running along the posterior limb of the internal capsule. There is a very low signal intensity in the anterior limb of the internal capsule (arrow). All this suggest the development of status marmoratus in this patient

  • Extrapyramidal cerebral palsy secondary to acute intrapartum near-total asphyxia is associated with bilaterally symmetric lesions in the posterior putamen and ventrolateral thalamus.
  • These lesions appear to be the correlate of the neuropathologic lesion called status marmoratus in the basal ganglia.
  • These are present in full-term infants with basal nucleus lesions resulting from acute total asphyxia.
  • The lesions have a marbled appearance caused by neuronal loss and an overgrowth of myelin in the putamen, caudate, and thalamus.

questions.text: The main objective of National AIDS Control programme III [NACP] is to address populations with high risk behaviours. Which among the following is the correct statement regarding Link worker scheme in NACP?
questions.solution:
Link worker scheme Programme:

  • National AIDS Control programme III [NACP]
  • Main objective: to address populations with high risk behaviours
  • Link worker: someone who is not “alien” to the neighbourhood, is accepted by the village community, and who can discuss intimate human relations and practice of sex and help equip high risk individuals and vulnerable young people with information and skills to combat the pandemic.
  • Population norm: One link worker per 5000+village population

questions.text: A 35-year-old male after RTA had fracture lower 1/4th of tibia in non-union with multiple scarred wounds and discharging sinuses and about 4 cm shortening of leg and this external fixator was done. What is the principle of this?
questions.solution:
• Shortening with discharging sinus ILIZAROV FIXATOR is the preferred method.

It uses the principal ofdistraction osteosynthesiswhich states that any living tissue when subjected to constant stretch under biological conditions, can grow to any extent.

The biological conditions are provided by:

  1. aligning the fracture with minimal damage to its vascularity, and
  2. performing an ‘osteotomy’ of the bone (e.g., in limb lengthening surgeries), without damaging its periosteal and endosteal blood supply.

Such an ‘osteotomy’ was termed corticotomy by Ilizarov

  • External fixator serves the purpose of wounds or open fracture but not limb shortening while ilizarov fixator serves both purposes

questions.text:
Identify the false statement/s about the mechanism of action of Barbiturates:

Decreases the effect of Glutamate by blocking the AMPA glutamate receptor.
On Low doses, they have GABA mimetic action.
Barbiturate binding site located between Alpha and Gamma subunits of Chloride ion channel receptor.
They activate the GABAA receptor, hence having a GABA facilitative action.
questions.solution:
BARBITURATES

  • Phenobarbitone and primidone act as anticonvulsant drugs due to GABA mimetic as well as GABA facilitatory properties.
  • These drugs increase the duration of the opening of chloride channels.
  • These drugs are useful in generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) and partial seizures.
  • These drugs are highly sedating but tolerance develops to this effect.
  • Phenobarbitone is a powerful enzyme inducer and increases the metabolism of several drugs including warfarin.
  • Barbiturates are contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.
  • These drugs can cause paradoxical excitation in some patients.
  • Phenobarbitone is the drug of choice for GTCS in infants but can cause hyperkinesia in older children.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with CAD develops sudden onset right side face and arm weakness and expressive dysphasia. On admission BP= 160/100 mm Hg. NCCT was done. Which is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• NCCT head shows Hyderdense MCA sign of acute ischemic stroke.

Hyperdense MCA sign- increased density within the middle cerebral artery on a non-contrast CT of the brain due to the presence of acute thrombus. This is one of the few signs that may be identified during the first few hours (hyperacute phase) of MCA territory infarction.

Acute ischemic stroke:

  • This sign indicates thrombus in the artery and is an early sign seen in cases of A.I.S.
  • Before the evolution of wedge-shaped hypodensity.
  • I/V Nicardipine & I/V Labetalol are not required as BP is not in the range of Hypertensive crisis.
  • Lowering this BP will reduce cerebral perfusion and worsen the patient.
  • Rx-
    • Mannitol is given when features of raised ICP are present.
    • Best step is thrombolysis with Reteplase

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presented with 7 weeks of pregnancy. She has complaint of vaginal spotting. USG shows empty uterus. Which of the following is the best treatment?

choices.text: If sac >3.5 cms, do medical management

• The USG finding of empty uterus indicates this case as ectopic pregnancy Management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy can be done by
Medical management Expectant management Surgical management
  • Serum hcg level < 3000IU/L
  • Gestational sac < 3.5cms
  • Hemodynamically stable patient
  • Tubal diameter should be less than 4cms without any fetal cardiac activity
  • There should be no intra-abdominal hemorrhage
  • If sac size < 3cm
  • HCG < 1000 IU/L and subsequent levels are falling
  • Laparoscopy is preferred over laparotomy

questions.text:
Which of the following features are true about Allergic Broncho Pulmonary Aspergilloma?

Distal bronchiectasis
Serum precipitins to Aspergillus
Increased IgE Levels
Seen in asthmatics
questions.solution:
A.B.P.A-Allergic Broncho Pulmonary Aspergilloma is common in asthmatics

  • C/O Black sputum plugs
  1. IgE ↑
  2. Sputum culture → A. fumigatus present.
  3. CT Chest- CENTRAL BROCHIECTASIS(characteristic feature of ABPA)
  4. S. Precipitins against Aspergillus species (Best way to diagnose)

Clinical features of ABPA:

  1. Bronchial obstruction with mucous plugs leading to breathlessness and repeated bouts of prolonged coughing.
  2. Thick sputum casts, usually brown or clear.
  3. Eosinophilia.
  4. CXR shows the presence of pulmonary infiltrates.
  5. CT chest shows central bronchiectasis.
  6. The cardinal diagnostic tests include
  • Elevated serum level of total IgE (usually >1000 IU/mL).
  • Positive skin-prick test to A. fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific IgE and IgG (precipitating) antibodies.

Criteria for the Diagnosis of ABPA:

1. SEROPOSITIVE ABPA (ABPA-S)

  • History of asthma (almost always difficult to control)
  • Elevated total serum IgE (usually >1000 IU/mL)
  • Immediate skin test reactivity to Aspergillus fumigatus OR elevated specific serum IgE to A
  • Fumigatus -Presence of serum precipitins (by gel diffusion) or elevated specific serum IgG to A. fumigatus

2. ABPA CENTRAL BRONCHIECTASIS(ABPA-CB)

  • The above criteria are positive  
  • Central bronchiectasis by high-resolution CT scan or CXR

3. OTHER SUPPORTIVE CLINICAL FINDINGS

  • Peripheral blood eosinophilia (often absent, especially if -Patient is on oral or inhaled corticosteroids)
  • Patchy, fleeting infiltrates (often absent, especially if the patient is on oral corticosteroids)
  • Expectoration of brown mucus plugs  
  • Mucoid-impacted bronchi evident on radiographic studies  
  • Sputum culture positive for A. fumigatus

Using the Patterson criteria ABPA may be considered to exist in two different forms: ABPA-seropositive (S) and ABPA-central bronchiectasis (CB)

questions.text: Which hormone is correctly matched with their second messenger?
questions.solution:
Option C: cAMP: Glucagon

Second messenger system Adenynyl cyclase-cAMP:

  • One of the ways of exerting intracellular actions is by stimulating the formation of the second messenger, cAMP, inside the cell membrane.
  • The cAMP then causes subsequent intracellular effects of the hormone.
  • Adenylyl cyclase-cAMP second messenger system stimulates the target tissues of many hormones. This is done by binding the hormones with the receptor, which allows coupling the receptor to a G protein. If the G protein stimulates the adenylyl cyclase-cAMP system, it is called Gs protein, which denotes the stimulatory effect. Stimulation of the Gs protein catalyzes the conversion of cytoplasmic ATP into cAMP inside the cell. This then activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase, which phosphorylates specific proteins in the cell, triggering biochemical reactions that ultimately lead to the cell's response to the hormone.
  • The image below shows the hormones that use the Adenylyl cyclase-cAMP system as a second messenger:
    • Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
    • Angiotensin II (epithelial cells)
    • Calcitonin
    • Catecholamines b receptors)
    • Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
    • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
    • Glucagon
    • Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)
    • Luteinizing hormone (LH)
    • Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
    • Secretin
    • Somatostatin
    • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
    • Vasopressin (V2 receptor, epithelial cells)
  • Signal Transduction Pathways:

Adenylyl Cyclase (cAMP)

Phospholipase C (IP3-Ca2+)

Cytoplasmic/Nuclear Receptor

Tyrosine kinase

Guanylate Cyclase (cGMP)

ACTH

GnRH*

Cortisol

Insulin

ANP

LH

TRH*

Estradiol

IGFs

Nitric oxide

FSH

GHRH*

Progesterone

GH

 

ADH (V2 receptor)

CRH*

Testosterone

 

 

PTH

Angiotensin II

Aldosterone

 

 

Calcitonin

ADH (V1 receptor)

Calcitriol

 

 

Glucagon

Oxytocin

Calcitriol

 

 

b-Adrenergic agonists

a-Adrenergic agonists

 

 

 

*also increase intracellular cAMP.

Option A: cGMP: Cortisol

  • All steroid hormones, e.g., cortisol, have cytoplasmic receptors, but estrogen has both cytoplasmic & nuclear receptors.

Option B:  Phospholipase C (IP3-Ca2+): ADH V2 receptor

  • ADH V2 receptor uses the Adenylyl cyclase cAMP second messenger system instead of the IP3-Ca2+, which many hormones use, as listed in the image above.

Option D: Tyrosine kinase: Nitric oxide

  • Receptor Tyrosine Kinases (RTK): Receptor for insulin, IGF, and other growth factors like PDGF Tyrosine Kinase–Associated Receptors such as Janus kinase or just another kinase (JAK) phosphorylates signal transducers and activator of transcription proteins (STAT): GH, prolactin, leptin.

questions.text: G1P0 at 8 weeks of gestation came to the hospital with complaints of bloody vaginal discharge. Per vaginal exam revealed closed internal ostium. Fundal height corresponds to the period of amenorrhea. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Threatened abortion

  • The patient presents with closed internal os with bloody vaginal discharge and the fundal height corresponds to the period of amenorrhea.

Inevitable abortion

  • Internal os is open and the fetus is in process of expulsion

Missed abortion

  • Internal os is closed but the fundal height is not corresponding to the period of amenorrhea

Incomplete abortion

  • Internal os is open and the abortion occurred but few products of conception are retained inside.

questions.text: A 13 years old boy, presented with complaints of puffiness of the face and hematuria. Hematuria was on and off for more than 5 years. He also complained of visual disturbances and progressive hearing loss for the last 2years. Alport syndrome was suspected in this patient. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition:
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome

  • Alport syndrome (AS) is a hereditary condition with an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance
  • Characterized by progressive, hematuric nephritis characterized by glomerular basement membrane abnormalities with frequent hearing defects and ocular anomalies.
  • AS usually presents with hematuria, proteinuria, progressive renal failure, ocular abnormalities, and sensorineural hearing deficits

X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance:

  • The features which suggest the X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance are-
  • A single abnormal X chromosome is sufficient to express the disease.
  • All of the female offspring of a diseased male XY will receive the abnormal X chromosome and express the disease, whereas none of the male offspring to the diseased father will have the disease (as sons don't receive an X chromosome from their father).
  • A diseased mother can transmit the abnormal X chromosome to both daughter and sons equally.

questions.text: A 70-year-old hypertensive patient presented to opd with complaints of sudden onset of palpitations, dizziness and loss of consciousness. On examination, his heart rate is 72 BPM and BP was 150/100. ECG was done which shows following findings. likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• ECG in lead II and other inferior leads show the presence of flutter waves( Sawtooth pattern).
  • 3-4 flutter waves before every narrow QRS complex.
  • Since the ventricular rate is 75 bpm (RR interval), atrial rate shall be obtained by multiplying the ventricular rate by 4 which is 300 bpm
  • The presence of risk factor of hypertension also give clue to the diagnosis of atrial flutter

questions.text: A female infant was born by NSVD at 41 weeks of gestation to a 25-year-old G2P2 mother. Delivery history was signi?cant for PROM for 22 hours. Apgar scores were 2 at 1 minute, 6 at 10 minutes, and 8 at 10 minutes of life. Poor scores were due to inadequate respiratory effort, and the infant was tracheal intubated in the delivery room. The exam at 10 hours of life was consistent with encephalopathy. According to Sarnat and Sarnat classification, if seizures has to occur in this baby it would happen at what stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Hypoxic Ischemic encephalopathy:

  • MC cause of seizures in neonates
  • MC neonatal seizure type - subtle seizures
  • Part of the brain most commonly involved in term neonates with HIE: Parasagittal area.
  • In preterm neonates- Periventricular area.
  • In Sarnat and Sarnat classification of HIE, seizures occur in Stage 2

Essential criteria for defining perinatal asphyxia include:

  • Persistence of APGAR score of 0-3 for >5 minutes
  • Prolonged acidemia (pH <7.0) on an umbilical arterial blood sample
  • Neurological manifestations, e.g. seizures, coma, hypotonia or hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in the immediate neonatal period
  • Evidence of multiorgan dysfunction in the immediate neonatal period

Staging Of Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

Stage I Stage II Stage III
Consciousness Hyperalert, irritable Lethargic Comatose
Tone Normal Mild Hypotonia Severe hypotonia
Moro Reflex Exaggerated Normal/depressed Absent
Autonomic Function Sympathetic overactivity Parasympathetic overactivity Both systems depressed
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Mid-dilated
Heart Rate Tachycardia Bradycardia Variable heart rate
Seizure Uncommon Common Uncommon
Prognosis 99% of cases have a good prognosis 80% of cases have a good prognosis 50% die; 50% have severe neurologic sequelae

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman posted for laproscopic hernia repair under general anaesthesia. The patient was induced with Inj. Propofol and endotracheal intubation facilitated with Inj. succinylcholine. Anesthesia was maintained with halothane, nitrous oxide and Inj. vecuronium. Intraoperatively, the patient develops masseter muscle spasm with blood pressure-180/100,pulse rate-150/minute, irregularly irregular rhythm,SpO2-95%,EtCO2-50 mmHg,Temperature-102oF. The most probable diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
• Malignant hyperthermia is a pharmacogenetic disorder inherited as autosomal dominant pattern.
  • Its susceptibility is linked to mutations in the skeletal muscle Ryanodine receptor (RyR1) and voltage gated calcium channel gene (CACNA 1S) that encode calcium channels necessary for skeletal muscle excitation contraction coupling.
  • Triggering agents - Halogenated volatile anaesthetics such as halothane and depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents (Succinylcholine)
  • Signs of Malignant hyperthermia (Hypermetabolic state)
    • Early signs
      • Elevated End tidal Carbon dioxide
      • Tachypnea and/or tachycardia
      • Masseter spasm if succinylcholine has been used
      • Generalised muscle rigidity
      • Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
      • Profuse sweating
      • Mottling of skin
      • Cardiac arrythmias
      • Unstable blood pressure
    • Late signs
      • Hyperkalemia
      • Rapid increase of core body temperature
      • Elevated creatine phosphokinase levels
      • Gross myoglobinemia and myoglobinuria
      • Cardiac arrest
      • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Treatment -
    • Discontinue all triggering anaesthetics
    • Administer Dantrolene
    • Supportive measures

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to your hospital with complaints of altered sensorium followed by seizure for one day. He had a history of chronic alcohol intake for about 25 years. He used to take around 750 ml of country-made alcohol daily. MR imaging showed low signal intensity in T1WI in the central portion of genu, body, and splenium of the corpus callosum suggesting demyelination. Your most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Marchiafavabignami disease:

  • It is a rare neurological complication of long-term alcohol use.
  • It is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, dysarthria, hallucinations, and intellectual deterioration. The pathophysiology is the demyelination of the corpus callosum, optic tracts, and cerebellar peduncles.

Wernicke’s encephalopathy:

  • It is an acute neurological complication characterized by the following symptoms (pneumonic GOA): G: Global confusion O: Ophthalmoplegia, usually 6th nerve palsy (second most common is 3rd nerve palsy) causing, horizontal nystagmus and gaze palsy) A: Ataxia

Korsakoff’s syndrome:

  • It is the chronic neurological complication of long-term alcohol use.
  • It is characterized by impaired recent memory, anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memory), retrograde amnesia (inability to recall old memories), and confabulations (making of false stories to fill memory gaps, which is unintentional). The anterograde amnesia is much more prominent than the retrograde amnesia

questions.text: A middle-aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails, and raindrop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above-mentioned symptoms is?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.
    • Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually occurs after 2–8 weeks of exposure.
    • Chronic poisoning may occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.
  • Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:
    • GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
    • Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
    • Skin symptoms: usually
    • begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
    • Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails) may also be seen.
    • Hairs: Alopecia occurs
    • Hematological: Anaemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are seen. Anaemia is normocytic and normochromic
    • Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory and motor polyneuritis (sensory symptoms usually predominate) manifesting as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
    • Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
    • Encephalopathy
    • Nephritis

questions.text: Electron microscopy findings of renal biopsy show permeation of the lamina densa of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) by a ribbon-like, homogeneous, extremely electron-dense material of unknown composition. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Dense-deposit disease (formerly called Type II MPGN)
    • Excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.
    • Electron M/E - Permeation of thelamina densaof the GBM by a ribbon-like, homogeneous, extremely electron-dense material of the unknown composition.
    • By immunofluorescence, C3 is present in irregular granular or linear foci in the basement membranes on either side but not within the dense deposits.
    • C3 is also present in the mesangium in characteristic circular aggregates (mesangial rings).
    • IgG is usually absent, as are components of the classical pathway of complement activation (such as C1q and C4).

questions.text: RW is a 67-year-old man who was transported to Acute Care Medical Center (ACMC) after being struck by a car while crossing First Avenue on foot. He has been hospitalized at ACMC for 6 days and is in the trauma ICU due to several fractures sustained in the motor vehicle accident. The patient developed fever and cough with sputum. The condition was diagnosed as ventilator associated pneumonia. Which of the following organism is most likely associated with VAP?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas is most likely associated with VAP (ventilator associated pneumonia).

Hospital acquired infections: occurs after 48 hrsof admission, during the process of care in a hospital or other health care facility, which was not present or incubating at the time of admission.

Causes of VAP:

Early onset VAP (within 4 days of mechanical ventilation) Late onset VAP (≥ 5 days after mechanical ventilation starts)
Pneumococcus Pseudomonas aeruginosa
H. influenzae Acinetobacter
MSSA (Methicillin sensitive S.aureus) E. coli
Klebsiella
MRSA (Methiciliin resistant S. aureus)

Clinical criteria for VAP:

CPIS score > 6: Diagnostic of VAP

Clinical Pulmonary Infection Score (CPIS) used for ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP) :

Parameter (s) Score 0 Score 1 Score 2
Temperature (°C) 36.5°C & 38.4°C 38.5°C & 38.9°C 39°C & 36.4°C
Leukocytosis 4000 & 11,000 < 4000 &> 12,000
Tracheal aspirate None Non-purulent Purulent
Oxygenation (PaO2/FIO2mmHg) > 250 or ARDS 250 & no ARDS
Chest radiograph No opacity Diffuse (patchy) opacity Localized opacity
Progressive radiological progression No radiological progression Radiological progression

Culture – Gram stain Different morphology Same morphology as Gram stain

questions.text: The umbilical artery gives rise to both a nonfunctional remnant of the fetal circulation and an active vessel giving supply to the bladder. In the adult, the obliterated area of the vessel is identifiable as the medial umbilical ligament, and the patent segment is the superior vesical artery. Which of the following states the hemoglobin-oxygen blood saturation in the umbilical artery?
questions.solution:
Option B: 60%.

Fetal circulation:

  • The fetal blood originates from two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein.
  • In fetal circulation, blood from the placenta through the single umbilical vein passes through the ductus venosus, mainly bypassing the liver.
  • This well-oxygenated blood from the placenta enters the left side of the heart through the foramen ovale. The blood is pumped from the left ventricle to the head and forelimbs via the arteries.
  • The blood entering the right atrium from the superior vena cava is directed downward through the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. This blood is mainly deoxygenated blood from the head region. It gets pumped by the right ventricle into the pulmonary artery, through the ductus arteriosus into the descending aorta, and through the two umbilical arteries into the placenta, where it gets oxygenated.

Option A: 40%

  • Umbilical artery hemoglobin-oxygen saturation is 60%.

Option C: 75%

  • Umbilical artery hemoglobin-oxygen saturation is 60%.

Option D: 97%

  • The uterine artery has a partial pressure of 100 mmHg and a hemoglobin oxygen saturation of 97.5%.

questions.text: Physiological leukocytosis is possible in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option D: ALL of the above

  • Physiological leukocytosis is seen in Infancy, Parturition, and Postprandial.

Physiological leukocytosis

  • Without tissue injury or infection, the increased number of circulating leucocytes has no clinical significance. It is seen in the following conditions:
    • Normal infants: The count can go as high as 18–20,000/mm3 and reach the normal level within 1–2 years.
    • Food intake and digestion ("digestive leukocytosis" ): There is a mild increase which returns to normal within an hour or so.
    • Mental stress.
    • Physical exercise.
    • Pregnancy: Especially during the first pregnancy, the count may be high.
    • Parturition: Due to tissue injury, pain, physical stress and bleeding, high TLC is possible.
    • Extremes of temperatures: WBC can increase when sun exposure or very low temperatures.

Option A: Infancy

  • Normal infants: The count can go as high as 18–20,000/mm3 and reach the normal level within 1–2 years.

Option B: Parturition

  • Parturition: Due to tissue injury, pain, physical stress, and bleeding, high TLC is possible.

Option C: Post prandial

  • Food intake and digestion ("digestive leukocytosis"): There is a mild increase that returns to normal within an hour or so.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are correct about chimney sweeps cancer except?

It’s a basal cell carcinoma of the scrotum
Diagnosis is established by biopsy
Para-aortic lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes involved
Treated by wide local excision
questions.solution:
CHIMNEY SWEEPS CANCER: CA SCROTUM

  • It is a squamous cell carcinomathat may present as an ulcer with an everted edge. It was the first reported occupational cancer.
  • The growth starts as a wart or ulcer and as it grows it may involve the testis. The tumor is diagnosed by biopsy.
  • The tumor should be excised with a margin of healthy skin. Inguinal lymph nodes are the first involved nodes.
  • The management of the inguinal nodes parallels the management of penile cancer and if nodal enlargement does not settle with antibiotics following treatment of the primary, then a bilateral groin dissection is indicated

questions.text: A 40-year-old female graduate student had an excruciating headache. When she looked in the mirror, she noticed that her eyelid was drooping; when she lifted the eyelid, she saw that her eyeball was looking down and out and her pupil was huge. She complained of both blurred and double vision. A magnetic resonance angiogram scan showed an aneurysm of the cerebral arterial circle. Which artery gives rise to the offending aneurysm?
questions.solution:

  • A communicatingartery mayharbor a berry aneurysm that impinges on the opticchiasm causinga bitemporal lower quadrantanopia.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are not considered as an indicator of poor prognosis in patients with systemic sclerosis?

Calcinosis cutis
Renal involvement
Alopecia
Telangiectasia
questions.solution:
• Patients with diffuse, rapid skin involvement have the highest risk of developing scleroderma renal crisis. Renal crisis occurs in about 10% of all patients with systemic sclerosis and is indicative of bad prognosis.
  • Renal crisis presents as accelerated hypertension, oliguria, headache, dyspnea, edema, and rapidly rising serum creatinine levels.
  • Renal crisis is observed within 4 years of diagnosis in about 75% of patients but may develop as late as 20 years after diagnosis.
  • Avoid high doses of corticosteroids since this is a significant risk factor for renal crisis

questions.text: A 8-year-old child presents with a history of chronic sinusitis and multiple nasal polyps. There is also a history of Recurrent chest infections and malabsorption syndrome. Which of the following tests would be useful in making a diagnosis?

choices.text: Tissue biopsy from the sinus cavity

questions.solution: The presence of chronic sinusitis, multiple nasal polyps, Malabsorption syndrome and recurrent chest infections point towards a diagnosis of Cystic fibrosis. Therefore a sweat chloride test is needed to make a diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old P2L2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan there is a complex ovarian cyst 4 x 5 cms in size with ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
• A history of congestive dysmenorrhea, ovarian cyst and HPE of endometrial glands is suggestive of endometriosis.
  • Protective factors against the development of endometriosis include
    • Multiparity
    • Lactation
    • Tobacco exposure in utero
    • Diet high in vegetables and fruits.
  • Risk factors for endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Early age at menarche
    • Shorter menstrual cycle length
    • Polymenorrhea
    • Nulliparity
    • Mullerian anomalies
    • Prior use of contraception or intrauterine device (IUD), or smoking is not associated with increased risk of endometriosis

questions.text: The defending team has appealed to the judge to make the information gathered during an inquiry as invalid as the concerned team had not followed the protocols as defined under CrPC 174. Which team's inquiry does the defendant's team have concerns about?
questions.solution:
• Important CrPC:
    • 2 CrPC: Gives various definitions (Bailable and non-bailable offence, Cognizable and Non Cognizable Offence, summons and warrant case etc.)
    • 39CrPC: Public to give information of certain offences (e.g. Homicide, kidnapping, robbery etc.) to nearest Magistrate or police officer
    • 53 CrPC: Examination of accused by medical practitioner at the request of police officer (Doctor can examine the arrested person even without his consent)
    • 54 CrPC: Arrested person can himself request the magistrate for his medical examination to get evidence in his favour.
    • 160 CrPC: Police officer has the power to summon any witness including doctor to police station for recording a statement.
    • 174 CrPC: Police Inquest
    • 176 CrPC: Magistrate inquest
    • 416 CrPC: High court may postpone the death sentence of a pregnant woman for any period and can even convert the death sentence to life imprisonment

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about insulinoma except:

choices.text: Most common functional endocrine tumour of pancreas
Most common site of insulinoma is tail of pancreas
72-hours fasting is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of insulinoma

questions.solution:
Insulinoma

Insulinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine neoplasmsand present with a typical clinical syndrome known as Whipple’s triad

The triad consists of

  • symptomatic fasting hypoglycemia
  • serum glucose level <50 mg/dL
  • relief of symptoms with the administration of glucose

Serum insulin and C peptide levels are elevated.The diagnosis can be clinched with a monitored fast in which blood is sampled every 4 to 6 hours for glucose and insulin levels until the patient becomes symptomatic. 72-hours fasting is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of insulinoma

Insulinomas are usually localised with CT scanning and EUS. Technical advances in EUS have led to preoperative identification of >90% of insulinomas. Visceral angiography with venous sampling is rarely required to accurately localise the tumour

Insulinomas are evenly distributed throughout the head, body and tail of the pancreas. The majority of insulinomas are benignand solitary and 10% are malignant. They are typically cured by simple enucleation

Approximately 90% of insulinomas are sporadic and 10% are associated with MEN1 syndrome

questions.text: The forensic doctor is doing the autopsy on a 35-year-old woman who had not survived the fire that had engulfed her hut. Staining of the post mortem lividity (hypostasis) revealed a Cherry red color thereby confirming poisoning with?

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the OPD with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. Endoscopy and manometry were done. Manometry revealed an abnormality in the peristaltic movement of the esophagus and LES relaxation. All of the following statements are correct about the motility disorders of the esophagus except:

choices.text: Best understood motility disorder of esophagus is achalasia
Most common hypermotility disorder of esophagus is Nut cracker oesophagus
Components of Triple A-syndrome or Allgrove disease are Achalasia, alopecia and ACTH- resistant Adrenal insufficiency
For hypertensive LES, laparoscopic modified Heller esophagomyotomy is the operation of choice

questions.solution:
Motility disorders of oesophagus

  • Motility disorders of oesophagus may be primary or secondary
  • Primary esophageal motor disorders include
    • Achalasia
    • Diffuse esophageal spasm
    • Nutcracker esophagus
    • Hypertensive LES
  • Achalasia
    • The best known and best understood primary motility disorder of the esophagus
    • It is due to degenerative changes in the vagus nerve and in the myenteric plexus of esophagus
  • Nutcracker esophagus / supersqueezeresophagus /jackhammer esophagus:
    • Most common of all esophageal hypermotility disorders
  • Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter
    • Surgery of choice - Laparoscopic modified Helleresophagomyotomy
  • TRIPLE A SYNDROME (ALLGROVE DISEASE) :
    • Achalasia
    • Alacrimia
    • ACTH Resistant Adrenal Insufficiency
    • It is a rare disease
    • Some cases are also associated with neurologic disturbances

questions.text: Which of the following is not the function of the hormone progesterone?

choices.text: Helps in the secretion of the glycogen and lipids

questions.solution:
Decreased levels of progesterone leads to the vasoconstriction and causes the peristalsis of the endometrium

Other functions of the endometrium are

It supports the endometrium

Vasodilation of the blood vessels supporting endometrium

It helps in the secretion of glycogen and lipids in the form of numerous vacuoles in liquid form to support the fertilized ovum.

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with discrete hypopigmented macules on his upper back, On examination of skin scrapings with 10% KOH under microscope spaghetti and meatball appearance was seen, for which Selenium sulfide is indicated as a treatment by the physician. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• PityriasisVersicolor or Tineaversicoloris a superficial infection of the skin caused byMalasseziafurfur (Pityrosporumorbiculare).
  • COLONY→ Yeast like consistency
  • CLINICAL FEATURES:presents with discretehyperpigmented or hypopigmented macules/scales (Refer to the image below)on chest or upper back.
  1. HIGHER incidence in tropics
  2. PREDISPOSING FACTORS:
  • perspiration
  • corticosteroids
  • malnutrition
  • hereditary
  • Immunosuppression

DIAGNOSIS: Microscopic Examination of Skin Scrapings:

  • scales + 10% KOH → SPAGHETTI & MEATBALL APPEARANCE (Refer to the image below)
  • scales + Wood lamp → Yellow Fluorescence
  • Scales + SDA & olive oil overlay [Lipophilic fungus] → FRIED EGG COLONIES

Treatment for T. Versicolor:-

  • Topical →Selenium sulfide, salicylic acid, a solution containing sulfur, terbinafine cream
  • Oral → Ketoconazole.

Answers to other options:

Tinea corporis: Oral terbinafine or itraconazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

The antifungal drugs recommended depends upon the type of candidiasis:

  • Cutaneous candidiasis or oral thrush – drug of choice is a topical azole
  • Esophageal and vulvovaginalcandidiasis – drug of choice is oral fluconazole
  • Disseminated candidiasis - drug of choice is Amphotericin B

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant has epispadias and the bladder mucosa is exposed to the outside. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text: Failure of urethral folds to fuse
Failure of the primitive streak mesoderm to migrate around the cloacal membrane

questions.solution: When the urinary bladder mucosa is open to the outside in the newborn, the condition is reffered to as extrophy of the bladder. The extrophy results from failure of the primitive streak mesoderm to migrate around the cloacal membrane, and it occurs often in combination with epispadias. Penile hypospadias is characterized by a failure of fusion of the labioscrotal folds, with the external urethral orifice located between the two unfused halves of the scrotum. Androgens are responsible for development of the testes. Klinefelter syndrome is a condition in which the male has 47 XXY chromosomes. A persistent allantois is associated with a patent urachus and an allantoic cyst.

questions.text: G1P0 woman came to the hospital with miscarriage in the 1st trimester. Which of the following is the most common cause of miscarriage in 1st-trimester abortion?

 22-32

 5-20
  • Triploidy
 6-8
  • Tetraploidy
 2-4
