questions.text:
Which of the following statement are true regarding panacinar emphysema:

It has tendency to occur more in lower zones and base of lung
It can cause clinically significant airflow obstruction
It is associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
It affects only bronchiole sparing the alveoli
questions.solution:
• Panacinar (panlobular) emphysema.
    • Acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.
    • Tends to occur more commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases.
    • Associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency (autosomal recessive).
    • Associated with micronodular cirrhosis
    • α1-anti-trypsin, normally present in serum, tissue fluids, and macrophages, is a major inhibitor of proteases (particularly elastase) secreted by neutrophils during inflammation. α1-anti-trypsin is encoded by a gene in the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14.
    • Population with homozygous for the Zallele(PiZZ), a genotype that is associated with markedly decreased serum levels of α1-anti-trypsin andhigher chance of emphysema.

questions.text:
All of the following are true about FAST except:

Performed within 8-10 minutes
Stratosphere sign or barcode sign is seen on
e-FAST in pneumothorax e-FAST has 8 views compared to FAST which only has 4 views
Subxiphoid transverse view assess pericardial sac
Suprapubic, longitudinal & transverse views assess the pelvis
questions.solution:
FAST (Focussed Assessment with sonography for trauma)

  • FAST: Emergency USG done very fast, performed within 2-4 minutes
  • Rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries
  • FAST is the first investigation done in blunt trauma abdomen: FAST has replaced DPL
  • 4 ‘P’s are evaluated in the sequence: pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Peri splenic region → Pelvis

e-FAST: 6 views

NOTE: In E-FAST of pneumothorax: STRATOSPHERE /BARCODE SIGN seen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the emergency department with two weeks history of shortness of breath, productive cough with yellow sputum, daily fevers, drenching sweats, unintentional weight loss of 20 pounds, and malaise. CT scan was done for the following with the given finding. All are the differential diagnosis of the condition shown in the CT chest, except?
questions.solution:
The CT Chest shows Miliary Mottling.

Seen in-

  1. Miliary TB
  2. Loffler pneumonia
  3. Bronchopneumonia
  4. Interstitial lung disease
  5. Hemosiderosis
  6. Sarcoidosis
  7. Silicosis

Diffuse pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis :- affects premenopausal women and presents with emphysema, recurrent pneumothorax and chylous pleural effusion.

  • HRCT → Multiple small thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung without zonal predominance.
  • Managed with sirolimus

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the second heart sound (S2) generated?
questions.solution:
Option A: Protodiastole

  • As the ventricular diastole starts, ventricular pressure begins to fall.
  • Blood ejected out during systole starts flowing back toward the ventricles due to the falling ventricular pressure.
  • This sudden change in the direction of blood marks the phase of protodiastole.
  • The closure of semilunar valves stops this regurgitation of blood toward the ventricles. This closure of semilunar valves produces (option-1) S2.
  • Thus, S2 indicates the end of the protodiastole; S2 is said to occur in protodiastole. After S2, the isovolumic relaxation starts.

 

Sound   Associated Events
S1 First heart sound (sounds like lub) Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves
  Two bursts, a mitral M1 and a tricuspid T1 component  
S2

Second heart sound (sounds like dub)

An aortic A2 and a pulmonary P2 component

 Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
OS Opening snap Opening of a stenotic mitral valve
S3 Third heat sound Diastolic filling gallop or ventricular or protodiastolic gallop
S4 Fourth heart sound The atrial sound that creates an atrial or presystolic gallop

 

Option B: Isovolumetric relaxation

  • When the ventricular pressure reduces significantly at the end of phase 4, the aortic and pulmonic valves close, causing the second heart sound (S2) and the beginning of the isovolumetric relaxation.
  • Valve closure is associated with the small backflow of blood into the ventricles and a characteristic notch in the aortic and pulmonary artery pressure tracings.

Option C: First rapid filling

  • When the ventricles continue to relax at the end of phase 5, the ventricular pressure will reduce their respective atrial pressure.
  • The AV valves rapidly open when this occurs, and passive ventricular filling begins.
  • Despite the blood coming from the atria, intraventricular pressure reduces because the ventricles are still relaxed.

Option D: Diastasis:

  • It is the middle stage of diastole during the cardiac cycle, where the initial passive filling of the ventricles has slowed, but before the atria contract to complete the active filling.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient was found unconscious under a tree and was brought to the emergency department where he regained consciousness. He said that he had taken shelter under a tree during a storm. He also said that he had remembered nothing after the sound of the lightning. His arterial BP was 130/75 mmHg, his pulse was 85 per minute, and his fingertip O2saturation was 98%. The results of a neurological examination were normal and his GCS score was 15. His hearing and the tympanic membrane were found to be normal. There were significant Lichtenberg figures on the patient's back, extending over the right scapula. These characteristic burns are also known as?
questions.solution:
• Filigree burns or Arborescent or fern-like injury or Lichtenberg figures
    • Pathognomonic for lightning injury
    • Superficial, irregular red marks, may follow skin creases, especially if damp from sweating. (fern-like pattern).
    • The erythematous marks are not burns.
  • Cause: Different authors have suggested different causes
    • The lesion occurs when an individual struck by a negative lightning bolt is then hit by a secondary positive flashover from a nearby grounded object.
    • It represents an entrance point in an individual struck by a positively charged lightning bolt.
    • Slight staining of tissues by haemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.
  • Option 1, Crocodile flash burns: Multiple burnt or punched-out lesions are produced due to the air dancing over the body surface over large areas.
  • Option 2, Adipocere: a variation of putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environments. In adipocere, fat undergoes hydrolysis to free fatty acids by virtue of endogenous lipases and bacterial enzymes.
  • Option 3, Mummification: Another modified form of putrefaction, where drying and desiccation of the tissues occur instead of liquefaction, depending upon the conditions prevalent at the terminal stages.

questions.text: A 12-day old breastfed baby who was brought by his mother presented with vomiting, poor feeding, and loose stools. On examination, the HR was 190/minute, BP - 50/30 mm Hg, RR - 68 breaths/minute, and capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Investigations show a Hb level of 15g/DL. Na - 12mEq/L, K-6.8 mEq/L, Cl-81 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L, Urea 30 mg/dL, creatinine 0.6 mg/dL. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Clinical profile of the baby given in question matches only with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (most probably 21 hydroxylase deficiency).
  • Clinical manifestations of 21-hydroxylase deficiency: Signs and symptoms of cortisol and aldosterone deficiency are produced.
  • Progressive weight loss
  • Dehydration
  • Vomiting
  • Anorexia
  • Weakness
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypoglycemia

Lab findings: Typical laboratory findings associated with cortisol and aldosterone deficiency including hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, acidosis, and hypoglycemia.

Point to the remember is that the other form of CAH like 17a hydroxylase and 1-B hydroxylase produce hypertension.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is found unresponsive and breathing rapidly in a park. He has no significant medical history other than moderate hypertension, for which he takes a b-blocker. Relevant laboratory findings are: Na+: 135 mEq/L K+: 4.5 mEq/L Cl-: 95 mEq/L HCO3-: 9 mEq/L Glucose: 40 mEq/L Serum pH: 6.8 Lactate: 9.5 mmoL/L. His son later revealed that the patient lost his job recently and has been quite upset about it for a few weeks.What metabolic process induced this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Overproduction of reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, hyperventilation, and lactic acidosis with hypoglycemia.

This presentation is consistent with ethanol-induced hypoglycemia. Oxidation of ethanol produces the reduced form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) in the liver via two key enzymes: alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase.

A high ratio of NADH to oxidized nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) induces pyruvate metabolism to lactic acid, which leads to lactic acidosis. Note the anion gap and the high lactate level. This elevated NADH / NAD ratio limits the supply of pyruvate needed for gluconeogenesis, hence hypoglycemia ensues.

questions.text: A disaster is a sudden, calamitous event that seriously disrupts the functioning of a community or society and causes human, material, and economic or environmental losses. In Disaster management, all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Maximum mortality is reported from hydrological disasters
Most common disease reported after disaster is gastroenteritis

questions.solution:
• Response is a post–disaster phase [not pre-disaster phase]. It is a part of Recovery phase after a disaster.

STAGES OF A DISASTER CYCLE

  • Disasters mitigation: Measures designed to either prevent hazard from causing emergency or to lessen the effects of emergency
  • Disasters preparedness
  • Disasters impact
  • Disasters response: search rescue & first aid, Field care, Triage, Identification of dead
  • Stage of health and medical relief: Disasters containment
  • Rehabilitation: Water supply, sanitation and personal hygiene, food safety, vector control.

TRIAGE

  • Carried out at the site of the disaster.
  • Done in order to determine transportation priority, and admission to hospital or treatment centre.

COLOR CODING

RED YELLOW GREEN BLACK
high priority treatment or transfer medium priority ambulatory patients dead/moribund patients

POST DISASTER PHASE (PDP)

  • M/C disease reported is acute gastroenteritis
  • M/C vitamin deficiency → vitamin A (B3, C)
  • Vaccine in PDP → All are C/I except measles

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese patient had undergone gastric bypass surgery in order to lose weight but he never came back for follow-up or continuing care. Three years later, he presents to an emergency room with fatigue, a glossy tongue, and macrocytic and hyperchromic anaemia. Which one of the following explains the patient’s condition correctly?

choices.text: The patient is suffering from Megaloblastic anaemia secondary to Folic acid deficiency
The patient has megaloblastic anaemia secondary to Vit.B12 deficiency
The patient is suffering from Lead poisoning
The patient anaemia is secondary to Gastrin deficiency

questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from B12 deficiency anaemia secondary to intrinsic factor deficiency.

Lead poisoning will lead to Microcytic Hypochromic anaemia and not macrocytic Hyperchromic.

Gastrin deficiency will lead to reduced acid production but it doesn’t lead to anaemia.

Vitamin B12 (cobalamine)

Source: only found in animal sources (deficiency is common in strict vegetarians)

  • Milk, curd, cheese
  • Egg, liver, meat, fish

Biochemical role:

  1. Homocysteine to methionine
  2. Methyl malonylCoA to succinylCoA
  3. Ribonucleotidereductase
  4. Leucine amino mutase
  • Absorption with the help of intrinsic factor

questions.text: Drug ‘A’ was administered to a patient admitted in ICU as an IV infusion after diluting it to the proper concentration in normal saline. Without changing any of the patient-related or the drug-related factors, Which of the following will determine how long will it take for the drug to reach steady-state concentration?

choices.text: Presence or absence of a systemic disease

questions.solution:
With IV infusion only the drug’s half-life can determine how long will it take for the drug to reach steady-state concentration.

The rate of infusion can affect how much is the concentration of the drug is remaining at the steady state. But it cannot determine the time it takes to reach it.

As the Bioavailability for IV infusion is 100% it doesn’t affect the time needed.

STEADY-STATE

  • If a fixed dose of a drug is administered after regular intervals, its plasma concentration starts increasing.
  • However, as plasma concentration rises, the rate of elimination also starts increasing. When the rate of administration becomes equal to the rate of elimination, plasma concentration stabilizes. This is called Steady-state.
  • The time to reach steady-state depends on t½. It takes approximately 4-5 half-lives.
  • Steady-state plasma concentration achieved depends on dose rate.
  • Variation between peak and trough concentration at steady state depends on dosing interval. However, average steady-state plasma concentration remains the same irrespective of dosing interval provided the dose rate remains the same.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, who went on a camping trip in the mountains of Ohio a week ago with his family, is brought to the emergency department because of a headache, rash, and the abrupt onset of high fever for 2 days. The rash began on his palms and soles but spread to his ankles and arms. On physical examination, he has palpable purpura on his wrists and lower legs. The infection is likely caused by?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rickettsia rickettsii

  • This patient’s travel history to mid-western states of the US followed by fever and characteristic rash involving the palms and soles is characteristic of rocky mountain spotted fever.
  • Infections with Rickettsia rickettsii, Treponema pallidum, and coxsackievirus all can cause a rash on the palms and soles.
  • This patient is most likely infected with R rickettsii.
  • The clinical course is typical for Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which is characterized by fever with an abrupt onset and a rash that spreads from the extremities toward the trunk.
  • Palpable purpura is a poor prognostic sign, as it indicates active vasculitis and leakage of blood into the skin.
  • The rash in syphilis and coxsackievirus is typically more gradual and is not typically preceded by travel to endemic areas.

Option B: Treponema pallidum

  • Eruptions are macular rashes and symmetrically distributed, almost always involving the face and forehead (individual lesions tend to be indurated; the colour may vary considerably, most often presenting as a subdued red rather than a bright red lesion)

Option C: Coxsackievirus

  • Vesicles surrounded by a thin halo of erythema eventually rupture and form superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base surrounded by an erythematous rim.
  • The exanthem can be macular, vesicular, or papular. The lesions are non-pruritic and typically not painful.

Option D: Disseminated Histoplasmosis

  • Characteristic lesions include nodules, papules, plaques, ulcers, vesicles, pustules, abscesses, and generalized dermatitis.
  • Less commonly, exfoliative erythroderma, necrotizing vasculitis, cellulitis, panniculitis, petechiae, purpura, and ecchymosis can be seen.

questions.text:
A patient presented with sudden onset eye pain and vomiting. On examination the below image is seen with shallow anterior chamber. What is correct regarding the immediate management in this condition?


Intravenous mannitol
Systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
YagIridotomy
Immediate surgery to reduce IOP
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of this patient is acute angle closure glaucoma

Image shows glaukomflecken: gray-white epithelial and anterior cortical lens opacities.

Occur following an episode of markedly elevated IOP, as in acute angle-closure glaucoma

Immediate management protocol in acute angle closure glaucoma

  • I.V. mannitol (DOC)
  • Oral hyperosmotic glycerol
  • Systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • Topical anti-glaucoma medications like pilocarpine, aqueous suppressants
  • Systemic painkillers and anti emetics
  • Avoid yag PI in acute stage as it can increase IOP by inflammatory reaction and inflamed iris is unresponsive.

questions.text: A randomized trial comparing the efficacy of two drugs showed a difference between the two (p<0.05). Assume that in reality, however, the two drugs to not differ. This is therefore an example of:-
questions.solution:
STATISTICAL ERRORS & P – VALUE

H0 rejected H0 not rejected
Null hypothesis (H0) trueNull hypothesis (H0) false Type I errorNo error No errorType II error
  • Type I error:
    • Null hypothesis is true but rejected.
    • Probability of type I error is given by ‘P value’. (probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present)
    • Significance (alpha) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of type I error.
    • Alpha is fixed in advance: p – value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha.
    • Keep type I error to be minimum (P
  • Type II error:
    • Null hypothesis is false butnotrejected. (or accepted)
    • Probability of Type II error is given by beta. (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)
    • Type I error is more serious than type II error

questions.text: A 62-year-old Chinese man was hospitalized for sudden-onset dizziness, diplopia, and gait disturbance. A neurological examination revealed seesaw nystagmus. Identify the pathology from the given picture.

  • Superior Oblique Palsy: SOP presents with the hypertropia, adduction and extortion. Horizontal movement abnormalities wont be there in it

During the lecture on the thorax, your Professor mentions that the paired ribs 8 to 10th are false ribs. He mentions that the 10th rib always forms …………… type of joint and 8 to 9 rib forms ………… type of joint respectively?

Synovial
Synchondrosis

questions.text: A 27-year-old Nigerian lady presents to the clinic with a history of mild anaemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and numerous blood transfusions. The blood film revealed 70 percent spherocytes, 6.5 percent reticulocytosis, enhanced osmotic fragility, and a negative direct antiglobulin test. She was treated conservatively with nutritional supplements, and her symptoms significantly improved after six months. Hereditary Spherocytosis was the diagnosis. Which of the following is the characteristic finding of this disease?

choices.text: Pigment-type of gall stones are common
Diagnosis can be made in neonatal period easily by examination of a blood film
Intravascular hemolysis is a common feature
Autosomal recessive inheritance in majority of the cases

questions.solution:
Option A: Pigment-type of gall stones are common

  • A hereditary Spherocytosis is a form of intrinsic hemolytic anaemia.
  • It is primarily an autosomal dominant disease.
  • It occurs due to a defect in protein interacting with the RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane. For example, ankyrin, spectrin, and Protein 4.2
  • Peripheral smear shows small round RBCs with a lack of central pallor. There is a decreased surface area of the RBCs

 

 

  • MCHC is usually increased. Premature removal of RBCs by the spleen leads to extravascular hemolysis.

 

 

  • Laboratory findings include splenomegaly, pigmented gall stones, aplastic anaemia, etc.
  • Decreased mean fluorescence of RBCs in the EMA binding test and increased fragility in the osmotic fragility test.
  • In hereditary Spherocytosis, there is a massive breakdown of RBCs, leading to the Destruction of RBCs and the release of bilirubin. Increased quantities of bilirubin can lead to the formation of gallstones.
  • In chronic hemolysis, pigmented stones are formed in the gall bladder. Pigmented gall stones are usually seen made up of bilirubin.
  • Anisocytosis and several hyperchromic spherocytes are seen.
  • Howell-Jolly bodies can be seen.

 

 

Option B: Diagnosis can be made in the neonatal period easily by examination of a blood film

  • In newborns, Spherocytosis & reticulocytosis are frequently minimal or absent.
  • So, diagnosis is not usually made in the neonatal period.

 

Option C: Intravascular hemolysis is a common feature

  • Hemolysis in hereditary Spherocytosis is mainly extravascular.
  • Splenomegaly usually results in hereditary Spherocytosis.

 

Option D: Autosomal recessive inheritance in the majority of the cases

  • 75% of cases of hereditary Spherocytosis have an autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance is seen in rare cases.

questions.text: For quite a while the "coxibs" (selective COX-2 inhibitors) were prescribed in preference to nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors for managing such conditions as rheumatoid arthritis. Now we have basically one drug in this class, celecoxib. Which statement best describes an action or property of this COX-2 inhibitor?

choices.text: Associated with a lower risk of gastric or duodenal ulceration
Cures arthritis, rather than just give symptom relief
Has a lower risk of adverse or fatal cardiac events

questions.solution:
Celecoxib, by virtue of selective COX-2 inhibition, does not interfere as much with the synthesis of PGE2?, which normally suppresses a component of gastric acid secretion and stimulates gastric mucus production. Overall, then, the risks of gastric and duodenal ulcers are reduced. The selectivity also means that COX-2 inhibitors do not interfere with the production of other eicosanoids, such as TXA2?. That is both good and bad, clinically. On the good side, this means that COX-2 inhibitors don't cause antiplatelet effects and increase the risk of excessive or spontaneous bleeding. On the other hand, this lack of effect renders them unsuitable for causing desired antiplatelet-aggregatory effects, as might be wanted when we administer aspirin. This may explain the finding that some COX-2 inhibitors have been associated with (cause?) higher risk of sudden cardiac death (D)in vulnerable patients, and why some have been pulled off the market (and are subjects of considerable litigation).

Selective COX-2 inhibitors, such as the nonselective alternatives, aren't cures for arthritis (B); they alleviate signs and symptoms but seem to have no demonstrable impact on the underlying pathophysiology. They have no effect on uric acid metabolism (C)or excretion. Their onsets of action are, overall, no faster (E)than those of a typical NSAID.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in image below and find the correct match in this keratoconjuctivitis

choices.text: Diagnosis is vernal keratoconjunctivitis and the drug of choice is olopatadine
Diagnosis is trachoma and drug of choice is streptomycin
Diagnosis is trachoma and most common cause of visual loss in trachoma is follicles
Diagnosis is trachoma and SAFE strategy is used by WHO for its prevention

questions.solution:
The figures shown arecharacteristic features of trachoma. Figure 1 shows Pannus with vascularisation. Figure 2 shows sago grain follicles.

It is the MC cause of infective blindness in world

Signs & Symptoms

  • In trachoma, tears ph is acidic.
  • Conjunctival congestion is seen in upper tarsal and forniceal conjunctiva, papillary hyperplasia seen
  • Hallmark:sago grain follicles
  • Conjunctival scarring - Linear scar present in sulcus subtarsalis -Arlt's line
  • Herbert'sfollicles -present at limbus,Herbet's pits seen -oval/ circular pitted scars left after healing of Herbert follicles.
  • Pannus: Progressive (infiltration of cornea is ahead of vascularisation) or regressive
  • Superficial keratitis and corneal opacity may be found.
  • Corneal scarring is the main cause of blindness in trachoma.
  • Trichiasis and cicatricial entropion may be seen.

CLASSIFICATION:

Mac Callan’s- divides into 4 stages :

  1. Incipient trachoma or stage of infiltration
  2. Established trachoma or stage of florid infiltration
  3. Cicatrising trachoma or stage of scarring
  4. Healed trachoma or stage of sequelae

WHO classification (FISTO):

  1. TF :Trachomatous inflammation - follicular
  2. TI : Trachomatous inflammation - Intense
  3. TS :Trachomatous Scarring
  4. TT :Trachomatoustrichiasis
  5. CO:Corneal opacity

Serotypes-

  • A,B,C- Hyperendemic Trachoma
  • D, K- Inclusion Trachoma

TREATMENT:

A. Treatment of active trachoma:

  • DOC:1gm azithromycin Single Dose
  • Other options :Doxycycline 100 mg BD 3-4 weeks
  • Topical therapy :Tetracycline Ointment (1 %) or erythromycin (1%) four times in a day for 6 weeks
  • Combined topical and systemic therapy- Preferred when ocular infection is severe (TI) or when there is associated genital infection.

B. Treatment of trachoma sequelae:

  • Concretions- removed with hypodermic needle
  • Trichiasis- treated by epilation, electrolysis, cryolysis
  • Entropion- to be corrected surgically
  • Xerosis- treated with artificial tears

C. Prophylaxis:

  • Hygienic measures
  • Early treatment of conjunctivitis
  • Blanket antibiotic therapy - in endemic areas. To apply 1% tetracycline eye ointment twice daily for 5 days in a month for 6 months
  • SAFE strategy is being employed by WHO

S: Surgery

A: Antibiotics

F: Facial Cleanliness

E: Environmental modification

Herbet pits
Arlt's line- on palpebral margin of upper lid

questions.text:
Which of the following statement are true regarding histological features of emphysema:

There is loss of attachments of the alveoli to the outer wall of small airways
The pores of Kohn become narrower and obstructed
It causes decrease in capillary bed area
There are large abnormal airspaces, blebs and bullae
questions.solution:
• Histological features of emphysema
    • Loss of attachments of the alveoli to the outer wall of small airways.
    • Pores of Kohn are enlarged that septa appear to be floating or protrude blindly into alveolar spaces with a club-shaped end. 
    • Prolonged vasoconstriction leads to changes of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
    • Alveolar walls are destroyed → decrease in the capillary bed area.
    • With advanced disease, there are even larger abnormal airspaces and possibly blebs or bullae, → deform and compress the respiratory bronchioles and vasculature of the lung.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with sphenoid sinusitis 3 days ago now presents with deep orbital pain, frontal headache and progressive paralysis of cranial nerves VIth, IIIrd and IVth in this order. Which of the following is the diagnosis of this patient:
questions.solution: Infection of the sphenoid sinus can rarely affect structures of the superior orbital fissure. The Symptoms of this syndrome consist of deep orbital pain, frontal headache and progressive paralysis of CN VI, III and IV, in that order.

questions.text:
Read the following statements about Monoclonal antibodies:

These are produced by fusing the polyclonal ‘B’ cells to myeloma cells after introducing an antigen into the mouse.
In the case of humanized Monoclonal antibodies the constant region is of human origin and the variable portion is of animal origin.
In the case of chimeric Monoclonal antibodies the constant region is of human origin and the variable portion is of animal origin.
Denosumab acts by inhibiting sclerostin and is useful in Osteoporosis.
Bevacizumab acts by inhibiting VEGF and are used in Diabetic Macular Edema.

Which of the above statements are true?
questions.solution:
Monoclonal Antibodies:

Monoclonal antibodies are produced by introducing antigen in a mouse and then fusing the polyclonal ‘B’ cells from the mouse’s spleen to myeloma cells.

There are three types of Monoclonal antibodies:

  1. Chimeric Monoclonal antibodies: The constant region is of human origin and the variable portion is of animal origin.
  2. Humanized monoclonal antibodies: Both the constant and variable region are from human origin and only the hypervariable portion is from animal origin.
  3. Human Monoclonal antibodies:100% of components are from human origin.

Denosumab acts by inhibiting the RANK ligands and used in Osteoporosis.

Bevacizumab acts by inhibiting VEGF, Used in CME, Macular edema and various cancers.

questions.solution:

  • But 25% occur in inherited syndromes such asfamilial medullary thyroid cancer and MEN types 2A and 2B

MEN2

  • Due to mutation in RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10
  • HPT develops in 20% of patients and is less severe
  • Hallmark of MEN2 syndrome- Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • First manifestation of the syndrome - Medullary thyroid carcinoma
MEN2A (Sipple’s syndrome) MEN2B (also known as MEN3)

Inheritance pattern Autosomal dominant Autosomal dominant
Associated abnormalities Phaeochromocytomas, hyperparathyroidism Phaeochromocytomas, multiple mucosal neuromas, mega colon, skeletal abnormalities (craniosynostosis), Marfanoid habits, abnormal dental enamel
Genetic defect Germline missense mutations in extracellular cysteine codons of RET Germline missense mutations in tyrosine kinase domains of RET

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with complaints of 2 months of progressively worsening pain and swelling of his right wrist and left ankle joints has come for consult. He did not report any fevers, chills, night sweats, weight loss or rash. All of the following facts related to the above-described disease and its pathology are true, except?

choices.text: It can be severe and progressive.
Granulomas are an example of the pathology described here
Dominant cells in the given disease are neutrophils.
It is involved in the pathogenesis of metabolic syndrome and certain cancers.

questions.solution:
• The given case describes a patient with Chronic inflammation of wrist and ankle.

Chronic inflammation is of longer duration and is associated with:-

  • Granulomatous reaction is a pattern of chronic inflammatory response.
  • Presence of macrophages (dominant cells), lymphocytes and plasma cells.
  • The proliferation of blood vessels, deposition of connective tissue.
  • It is severe and progressive.
  • Chronic inflammation is implicated in pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases, metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes and certain cancers.
  • White adipose tissue produces cytokines such as TNF, IL -6 , IL -1, and IL -18 chemokines and steroid hormones. The increased production of cytokines and chemokines by adipose tissue in obese patients creates a chronic proinflammatory state marked by high levels of circulating C-reactive protein. (pg447)

questions.text: A 23-yrs-old woman (gravida 2, para 2) calls her physician 7 days postpartum because she is concerned that she is still having an altered discharge from the vagina. Which of these would be appropriate advice regarding normal lochia?

choices.text: Normal lochia lasts for 2 days and she should immediately seek medical attention
Normal lochia lasts upto 7 days and she should seek medical attention if it persists
Her discharge is lochia rubra along with infective secretions from uterus and should take antibiotics
Normal lochia usually lasts 10-14 days but may last upto 3-5 weeks

questions.solution:
• Lochia is vaginal discharge resulting from sloughing of decidual tissue.
  • It contains erythrocytes, shedded decidua, epithelial cells and bacteria.
  • The average duration of lochia discharge ranges from 24 to 36 days

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy who committed a crime was brought by a constable for a check-up before taking him to Juvenile Detention Centre. Your senior doctor has examined the patient and marked his sexual maturity status as Tanner stage 3. Out of the following statements which is/are true regarding the Tanner stage III?

Hair growth darker, coarser, and curried across the man's pubis
Darkening of scrotum
The glans (head) of the penis becomes more prominent
The penis grows in length and the testes and scrotum continue to grow
Genitalia reaches adult size and shape
questions.solution:
Classification of sexual maturity status in boys:

Stage 1:

  • Prepubertal
  • No public hair and genitals proportionally the same as in childhood.

Stage 2:

  • Sparse hair growth at the base of the penis- slightly darkened
  • Scrotum and testes enlarge, Scrotum thins and reddens.

Stage 3:

  • Hair growth darker, coarser, and curried across the man's pubis
  • The penis grows in length and the testes and scrotum continue to grow

Stage 4:

  • Hair growth denser; coarse and curly like in an adult, but not yet spread to inner thighs
  • The penis continues to grow; the glans (head) of the penis becomes more prominent
  • The scrotum darkens.

Stage 5:

  • Hair growth extends to the inner thighs
  • Genitalia reaches adult size and shape.
  • The first visible sign of puberty is testicular enlargement*
  • It begins around 9-10 years
  • Testicular volume is assessed using an orchidometer*
  • Growth spurt occurs in SMR 4 or when the testis volumes reach approximately 9-10 sq. cm

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding sarcoidosis?

Schumann bodies and asteroid bodies are seen
BAL (Broncho-alveolar lavage) fluid shows CD8 / CD4 T cell ratio of 4:1
Hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes are spared
Can be associated with unilateral or bilateral iritis or iridocyclitis
questions.solution:
• Sarcoidosis
  • The lungs are involved is seen in 90% cases.
  • Clinical manifestations include lymph node enlargement, eye involvement (sicca syndrome [dry eyes], iritis, or iridocyclitis), skin lesions (e.g., erythema nodosum), and visceral (liver, skin, marrow) involvement.
  • Lymph nodes are involved in almost all cases, particularly the hilar and mediastinal nodes.
  • Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD4+ T cells, resulting in CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios ranging from 5:1 to 15:1.
  • Schumann bodies and asteroid bodies are seen on microscopic examination. These are not pathognomonic of sarcoidosis because these may be seen in other granulomatous diseases (e.g., tuberculosis).

questions.text: A lady with 38 weeks of pregnancy is admitted in view of first episode of painless bout of bleeding yesterday. O/E: Hb 10.5g%, BP 124/78 mmHg, uterus relaxed, and head is un-engaged and floating. FHS regular. Next line of management is?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of placenta previa (painless bleeding, relaxed uterus, and floating head all point to placenta previa).
  • Since the lady is already 38 weeks, there is no need for conservative management since maturity is already achieved. The best management is a Caesarean section here
  • # If the same patient presented at less than 36 weeks, the answer would be wait and watch.
  • # If there was fetal distress at any stage after 28 weeks with APH, the answer would be LSCS
  • # If there was maternal hemodynamic instability, the answer would be blood and IV fluids, followed by emergency LSCS.

questions.text: A newborn baby is born with ambiguous genitalia and a 46,XY karyotype. A few hours later the child develops vomiting, low serum sodium concentration, and high serum potassium. Which of the following is most likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Sex steroids are synthesized from cholesterol by side-chain cleavage (employing a P450 enzyme) to produce pregnenolone.
  • Pregnenolone is then converted to testosterone in the testis, to estrogen in the ovary, and to corticosterone and aldosterone in the adrenal gland.
  • The enzymes 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, 21-hydroxylase, 11β-hydroxylase, and 18-hydroxylase modify pregnenolone to produce other sex and adrenal steroids.
  • Deficiencies in adrenal 21-hydroxylase can thus lead to inadequate testosterone production in males and produce ambiguous external genitalia.
  • Such children can also exhibit low sodium and high potassium due to deficiency of the more distal steroids cortisol and aldosterone.
  • 17-Hydroxylase converts progesterone to 17-α-Progesterone which then converted to cortisol, testosterone and estrogen. There won’t be saltwater wasting in case of 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Defective of the androgen receptor is called testicular feminization, producing normal-looking females who may not seek medical attention until they present with infertility

questions.text:
Which of the following features are correct about Conus Medullaris syndrome?

Plantar Extensor
Absent knee & ankle jerks
Sacral anesthesia
Lower sacral & coccygeal involvement
questions.solution:
• The root value of Conus medullaris is S1-S5.
  • Hence in conus medullaris syndrome, knee-jerk is preserved but ankle jerk is lost.
  • Due to the involvement of corticospinal pathway, extensor plantars will be seen

questions.text:
(A) True or (B) False about Rett’s syndrome

It is characterized by normal development till the age of 2 years.
Occurs exclusively in females
Child gradually develops stereotyped hand movements such as hand wringing, licking, or biting of fingers
75% of children with this syndrome have seizures
questions.solution:
Rett’s disorder (Rett’s syndrome):

  • Earlier it was believed that Rett’s disorder occurs exclusively in females, however, late males with similar presentation have been described.
  • It is characterized by normal development till the age of 5 months. Between 5-48 months, the child starts to lose acquired hand skills (such as fine motor skills) and there is loss of acquired speech.
  • Also, there is the deceleration of head circumference producing microcephaly.
  • The child gradually develops stereotyped hand movements such as hand wringing, licking, or biting of fingers.
  • The language function remains impaired and there is also a loss of social interaction. The child also develops poorly coordinated gait or trunk movements
  • Along with these symptoms around 75% of children have seizures. The disorder is usually progressive and treatment is symptomatic

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct about placental separation?

Duncan separation starts from the margin and it is the most common type
Schultze separation starts from the center and the blood accumulates retroplacentally
Uterus becomes globular and firm before separation
Uterus becomes discoid after separation
questions.solution:
• Uterus become discoid before separation and globular & firm after separation
  • Before separation:
    • Uterus becomes discoid in shape, firm in feel and non-ballotable
    • Fundal height reaches slightly below the umbilicus
  • After separation:
    • Uterus becomes globular, firm and ballotable
    • Fundal height is slightly raised
    • Sudden gush of vaginal bleeding upon separation
    • Permanent lengthening of cord
  • The separation is facilitated partly by uterine contraction and mostly by weight of the placenta as it descends down from the active part
  • Two types of separation:
    • Marginal separation:
      • Mathews-Duncan separation and starts from the margin. It is the most common type
    • Central separation:
      • Schultze separation which starts at center, blood accumulates retroplacentally until whole of the placenta gets detached.

questions.text: A 25 year old male returning from South America to India was kept in quarantine by the airport authorities. Due to recent advances in Health care system, quarantine has been replaced nowadays by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Quarantine has been replaced with active surveillance.
  • Quarantineis the restriction of activities of apparently healthy persons who have been exposed to a case of communicable disease during its period of communicability, for the duration of it's maximum incubation period.
  • Active surveillanceis the continuous scrutiny of all aspects of a disease and application of information to heath promotion and to disease prevention and control

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is admitted with postpartum eclampsia. While on magnesium sulphate therapy she develops bradypnea and her SpO2 drops to 55%. She is quickly intubated and started on invasive ventilation. Among various lab tests, the doctor orders Mg2+ levels, which are expected to be?
questions.solution:
• During Magnesium toxicity, the first reflex to be lost is patellar reflex (loss of knee jerk)
  • While giving MgSO4 things should be monitored are as follows;
    • Respiratory rate should be at least more than 12
    • Output should be more than 100 ml / 4hrs
    • Knee jerks should be present
Serum Mg2+levels(meq/l) Clinical effects
4-7 Normal therapeutic level
8 – 10 Patellar reflex disappear
10-15 Respiratory depression
12-15 Respiratory paralysis
25 – 30 Cardiac arrest
  • Treatment is with calcium gluconate 1 g IV

questions.text: A 47-year-old female who is working as a staff nurse in a local PHC was referred to your hospital with a one-month history of continuous abdominal pain and distension, accompanied by fever, night sweat, and significant weight loss. Barium meal follow-through was done. The Radiological sign shown in the image is?
questions.solution:
On Barium meal follow through

In GI TB →contraction of mesocolon

  1. Pulled – up cecum
  2. Obtuse I/C Angle
  3. Goose Neck Deformity
  • Rapid uptake of barium into colon due to Formation of Transverse ulcers in ileum which causes hyper irritability→ Narrowed appearance of ileum aka “STERLEIN SIGN”.
  • Persistent narrowing due to strictures – STRING SIGN OF KANTOR
  • Sterlein sign & string sign of Kantor – are seen in GITB, as well as Crohn’s disease.
  • In chronic cases, thickened IC valve, rigid cecum, narrowed ileum is known as UMBRELLA SIGN/ FLIESHER’S SIGN

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of swelling in the medial aspect of the upper thigh region. On further evaluation, patient was found to have a femoral hernia. All of the following statements are correct about femoral hernia except:

choices.text: Lockwood operation is the treatment of choice
In Cloquet’s hernia, sac lies under the pectineus fascia
Should be operated on as soon as possible

questions.solution:
Femoral hernia:

Femoral hernia more common in female

  • ↑ risk of strangulation
  • appears below and lateral to the pubic tubercle and lies in the upper leg

Treatment:

Midline abdominal extraperitoneal femoral hernioplasty (henry procedure) is now considered of choice; does not damage the transversalis fascial floor; reducing the risk of a subsequent inguinal hernia

  • Low inguinal operation (Lockwood) [ simplest but suitable only when there is no risk of bowel resection]
  • Inguinal operation (lotheissen)
  • High inguinal operation (McEvedy) [ ideal in the emergency situation where the risk of bowel strangulation is high]

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the ER with complaints of shortness of breath and chronic cough which had been present for 24 months. He is a heavy smoker and has a long history of cardiac illness. Which of the following Bronchodilators will be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Inhaled β2 agonists are the agents of choice for the termination of an acute attack of bronchial asthma.
  • However, as the patient is having a history of cardiac illness, β2 agonists are used
  • Therefore, other bronchodilators like anticholinergic agents (ipratropium) or methylxanthines (theophylline) will be useful in such a case.

questions.text: A 3 months old female child was brought to the hospital, with complaints of involuntary movements of left hand and fingers for one day. The child was alert and was smiling at the mother during the time of involuntary movements. On examination, the child had multiple hypomelanoate macules (ash leaf) over back, trunk, chest, abdomen, thigh, and gluteal region. The child also had the following finding shown in the given image. The probable mutation responsible for this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Ungualfibroma

From the given data, it is clear that this is a case of Tuberous Sclerosis

Tuberous Sclerosis:

  • Mutations in the TSC1 (chr 9) or TSC2 (chr 16) gene can cause tuberous sclerosis complex
  • Skin manifestations include ash leaf macules, adenoma sebaceum, cafe au lait spots, and shagreen patches.
  • CNS manifestations include developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures, and autism.
  • Other organs involved include kidneys (angiomyolipomas), lungs (lymphangiomyomatosis), heart (rhabdomyoma), and retina (hamartomas).

**MAJOR CRITERIA FOR TUBEROUS SCLEROSIS (AT LEAST 2 NEEDED TO DIAGNOSE)

  • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Ungualfibroma
  • Shagreen patch
  • Hypomelanotic macules (≥3)
  • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
  • Angiomyolipoma of kidney
  • Retinal hamartoma
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Astrocytoma (giant cell)
  • Subependymal nodules
  • Tubers (cortical)

questions.text:
Mark theCORRECTstatement about the corneal dystrophy demonstrated in the picture below:


Decrease in endothelial cell count
Silver beaten appearance
Seen in old age
Can present with edema in morning
questions.solution:
Image demonstrates the corneal endothelium with increased gaps in-between cells called Guttata. This is seen in Fuch's Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy

Fuch’s Endothelial Dystrophy

It is characterized by bilateral accelerated endothelial cell loss.

  • Inheritance - Mostly sporadic, occasionally autosomal dominant
  • Symptoms
    • Common in women, middle age or later onset
    • Gradually worsening blurring of vision especially in the mornings due to overnight corneal edema
  • Signs
    • Characteristic gutta are seen- irregular warts or excrescences on Descemet's membrane
    • Specular reflection shows dark spots due to disruption of the regular endothelial mosaic
    • Can progress to a beaten metal appearance
    • Endothelial cell loss leads to gradual central stromal edema and blurred vision worse in the morning and corneal thickening
    • Advanced cases, epithelial edema develops which can lead to formation of microcysts and bullae with subsequent complications
    • Cataract Surgery can worsen corneal endothelial status and precipitate endothelial cell loss and lead to bullouskeratpathy. Greater chances of this if central corneal thickness is 630-640 μm
  • Management
    • Hypertonic saline eye drops for reducing corneal edema
    • Management of BullousKeratopathy in advanced cases by Lubricants, IOP reduction, Bandage contact Lens, cycloplegics
    • Posterior Lamellar Keratoplasty - Descemet Membrane Stripping Endothelial Keratoplasty (DSAEK) or Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty (DMEK)(Treatment of choice)
    • Severe cases with stromalopacification may require Penetrating Keratoplasty

Granular Dystrophy

Apple green birefringence is seen in the lattice dystrophy due to amyloid deposition

Macular Dystrophy

Lattice Dystrophy

questions.text: Many native human beings in the Andes and in the Himalayas live at altitudes above 13,000 feet. These natives will show all the following as compared to their lowlander counterparts EXCEPT:

choices.text: Left shift of O2 Hb curve
Low ventilatory capacity to body mass ratios

questions.solution:
The natives are superior to even the best acclimatized lowlanders in all aspects of acclimatization, even though the lowlanders might have lived at high altitudes for 10 or more years. Acclimatization of the natives begins in infancy. The chest size, especially, is greatly increased, whereas the body size is somewhat decreased, giving a high ratio of ventilatory capacity to body mass. The hearts of natives, which from birth onward pump extra amounts of cardiac output, are also considerably larger than the hearts of lowlanders.

Fig: Oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves for blood of high-altitude residents (red curve) and sea – level residents (blue curve), showing the respective arterial and venous PO2 levels and Oxygen contents as recorded in their native surroundings. (Data from Oxygen- dissociation curves for bloods of high – altitude and sea- level residents. PAHO Scientific Publication No. 140, Life at High Altitudes, 1966.)

questions.text: Sexually transmitted disease is an infection transmitted through sexual contact, caused by bacteria, viruses or parasites. The use of condom for protection against sexually transmitted diseases qualifies as which of the following?
questions.solution:
This is an example ofprimary preventionsince we are trying to prevent the occurrence of the disease though the risk factors are present.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant girl was brought to her family physician with a concern that she was unable to raise her upper body when lying prone. Her parents stated that she had made no attempts to roll over, rarely moved her legs, and made no attempts to push with her feet when held upright. On examination, there are tongue fasciculations and she keeps her body in a frog-like position. All of the following can cause this condition except:
questions.solution:
• Features of hypotonia and frog-like position suggest the diagnosis of Floppy infant syndrome.
  • There are many causes of floppy infant syndrome.
  • Out of the four options given in the question three of these can cause FIS -
    • Downs syndrome
    • G.B. syndrome
    • Spinal muscular atrophy
  • Floppy infant syndrome refers to infants which have hypotonia (floppy).
    • The infant cannot hold his head up and there is marked head lag as the baby is pulled up from supine to sitting posture.
    • A normal infant, on ventral suspension (i.e. supporting the infant with a hand under the chest), keeps his back straight and head slightly up, arms abducted, and knees partly flexed. A floppy infant droops, over the hand like an inverted U.
  • There is decreased muscular activity, frog-like posture, and delayed milestones.
  • Important causes of FIS are:-
  1. CNS: Perinatal asphyxia, kernicterus, cerebral palsy, intracranial bleed, Down syndrome
  2. Spinal cord lesions: Werdnig Hoffman spinal muscular atrophy, Poliomyelitis (both are motor neuron diseases).
  3. Peripheral nerves: Acute polyneuropathy, familial dysautonomia, congenital sensory neuropathy.
  4. Myoneural junction: Infantile botulism, neonatal myasthenia gravis.
  5. Muscles: Muscle dystrophies, congenital myopathies, polymyositis, Pompe's disease.
  6. Miscellaneous: Rickets, PEM, cretinism, Ehler-Danlos syndrome, Prader - Willi syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-yr-old tender coconut seller accidently got injured his wrist while cutting the tender coconut. There is the incised wound in the front of the wrist which is 3cm length, 5cm width and 2cm depth and the patient is unable to oppose the tip of the little finger and the thumb. The nerves involved is/are:

choices.text: Reccurent branch of median and radial nerves

questions.solution:
• Incised wounds in front of the wrist damagesmedian nerveoften, butulnar nerve may also get involved.
  • Opposition of the tips of little finger and thumb requires opponens pollicis (median nerve) and opponensdigitiminimi (ulnar nerve) as well.
  • In Carpal tunnel syndrome also pt is unable to oppose the thumb

questions.text: 37 weeks G2P1L1 is admitted with pain in abdomen since 2 h. O/E: Hb = 9 g%, BP 150/90 mmHg, and urine albumin +. P/A—36 weeks, fetal heart rate good with minimal contraction of uterus. P/V—6 cm dilated. ARM reveals blood-stained liquor. Next line of management is:

choices.text: Blood transfusion and wait for spontaneous progress of labour

questions.solution:
• This is a case of revealed abruption (pain, preeclampsia, and blood-stained liquor) all point to the diagnosis of abruption

  • In abruption the aim should be to deliver the patient soon, as the bleeding stops only after the delivery of the placenta.
  • If there is fetal distress immediate LSCS should be done.
  • If the fetus is alive and there is no fetal distress and there is a possibility that delivery can happen soon (as in this case) then labor should be augmented by ARM and oxytocin drip, keeping a close watch on FHR.
  • So, remember that abruption is not an absolute indication for LSCS, it is a relative indication.

questions.text: A 71-year-old male presented to hospital with a one-day history of fever with rigors, nausea and weakness followed by profuse watery diarrhoea. The patient deteriorated rapidly during the evening, and on admission to hospital the following morning was noted to be febrile and hypotensive, with a decreased level of consciousness and continuous green watery diarrhoea. Soon after moving her to the ICU, a subcutaneous haemorrhage-like, extremely painful skin rash appeared and extended rapidly over her leg. Suspecting gas gangrene, sample was sent to microbiology laboratory. The microbiologist decided to perform Nagler's test on egg yolk agar. Nagler's test is used for which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Nagler's reaction is used forCl. perfringens.

Above clinical condition is suggestive ofClostridial myonecrosis / gas gangrene.

Reactions of Clostridium perfringens:

1. Nagler’s reaction:

  • It is a biochemical test used toidentify organisms (Eg: Clostridium perfringens) that liberate phospholipases (lecithinases).
  • Bacterial lecithinase break down the lecithin (a normal component of egg yolk) to insoluble diglycerides resulting in an opaque halo.
  • Procedure:
    • The media used isEgg yolk mediumwhere Clostridium is inoculated in two streaks (one is of test organism and other is control organism).
    • On one half of the culture plate anti-toxin is added , on the another half there is no antitoxin.
    • Neutralization occurs between antitoxin and α lecithinase toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens.
    • An opalescent halo is formed around colonies that produce lecithinase (Clostridial α-toxin).

2. Stormy fermentation in litmus milk

3.Target haemolysis:Double zone haemolysis (Refer to the images below).

Inner zone:due tothe theta toxin

Outer zone:due toalphatoxin.

questions.text: A 38 years old female came to the ER with complaints of lower abdominal pain associated with fever for 24 hours. The patient is on copper IUD contraception for the last 4 years. On examination, lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness was present. You are suspecting PID in this patient. Which of the following is the most likely organism to be associated with PID in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The organism associated with PID in women who are IUCD users is actinomyces.
  • It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the devices is worn for more than 2 years, compared to 1% in non-users
  • This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict follow up of women wearing these devices.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman was admitted to the psychiatric unit because the patient was complaining that she was dead, smelled like rotting flesh, and wanted to be taken to a morgue so that she could be with dead people. She also admitted to hopelessness, low energy, decreased appetite, and somnolence. This type of delusion is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
• From the given data it is clear that the patient is having Nihilistic delusion
  • Patients with severe depression may develop psychotic symptoms (delusions and hallucinations).
    • These psychotic symptoms could be mood-congruent (i.e. content of delusion/hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood, e.g. the severely depressed patient developed a delusion that the world is about to end, nihilistic delusion) or
    • It can be mood incongruent (i.e. content of delusion is inconsistent with the depressed mood, e.g. a severely depressed patient developed the delusion that he is the richest man on earth).
    • It must be remembered that psychotic symptoms are present only in severe depression and sometimes the term “psychotic depression” is used for depression with psychotic features.
  • Psychotic symptoms (In this case the nihilistic delusion) are seen more commonly in both endogenous and melancholic depression (depression in the involutional stage).
  • It can also be seen in double depression, though less commonly (double depression is depression superimposed over dysthymia)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker plumber by occupation presented with complaints of dyspnea, chronic cough. CT thorax showed bilateral pleural plaques at the basal areas of lungs, fibrotic changes. Transbronchial biopsies showed findings as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image is showing Ferrugenous bodies which are seen in asbestosis.
  • Ferruginous body/ Asbestos body appears as a yellow, beaded structures with clubbed ends. proteinaceous material with iron.
  • Asbestos exposure is a well-known risk factor for the development of mesothelioma.
  • At risk are people working in plumbing and insulation.
  • Most commonly involves base of the lung.

Ingested 2000 Jejunum 5500
Salivary gland 1500 Ileum 2000
Stomach 2500 Colon 1300
Bile 500    
Pancreas 1500    
Intestine 1000    
Stool= total input-reabsorbed= 200 ml

Option C: Bile 500 ml/day

questions.text: A community has total population 10000. Children ranging 0-6 years are 2000. Literate persons among > 7 years of are 4000. What is Effective literacy rate?
questions.solution:
• Effective literacy rate (ELR) = no. of literates / Total population > 7 years age X 100

In the given question,

  • Total population = 10000, Population 0-6 years age = 2000
  • So population > 7 years age = 10000-2000 = 8000
  • So ELR = 4000/8000 X 100 = 50%

questions.text: Arboviruses are viruses that are maintained in nature principally, or to an important extent, through biological transmission between susceptible vertebrate hosts by hematophagous (blood-sucking) arthropods. Which of the following statements is true regarding Arbo-viruses?

choices.text: Yellow fever is endemic in India
Kyasanur forest disease is transmitted by ticks
Mosquito of culexvisnoi complex is the vector of dengue fever
Dengue virus has only one serotype

questions.solution:
Discussing options one by one:

  • Option-1 - False - Yellow fever is not present in India.
  • Option-2 - True- Kyasanur forest disease is transmitted by ticks.
    • In india: hard tick.
    • Outside India: soft ticks.
  • Option-3 - Flase - Aedes aegypti mosquito is the vector of dengue fever; Culex is vector of JE.
  • Option- 4 - False - Dengue virus has four serotypes.
    • There is no lifelong immunity against dengue

questions.text: A 56-year-old postmenopausal female with complaints of lump breast with blood discharge underwent FNAC which revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. All of the following statements are correct about carcinoma breast except:

questions.solution:

MC histological subtype Invasive ductal Ca
MC site Upper outer quadrant
Least common site Lower inner quadrant
MC metastasis to Bone > Lung> Pleura > Soft tissues > Liver

questions.text:
All of the following are correct about bronchial carcinoid except:

More common in smokers
Carcinoid syndrome is uncommon
Most tumors are confined to the main stem bronchus
Most bronchial carcinoids are amenable to resection
Some tumors penetrate the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribranchial tissue producing the collar-button lesion
questions.solution:
BRONCHIAL CARCINOID

  • Bronchial carcinoids (least malignant) are the most indolent of the spectrum of pulmonary neuroendocrine tumors
  • Most patients are < 40 Years;Not related to smoking
    • The lower respiratory tract (Bronchus, lung, trachea) is the MC site of carcinoid tumor
    • Carcinoid syndrome is uncommon

Pathology

  • Most tumors are confined to the main stem bronchus, commonly projects into the lumen
  • Some tumors penetrate the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribranchial tissue producing the collar-button lesion
Most bronchial carcinoids
  • Do not have secretary activity
  • Do not metastasize to distant sites
  • Are amenable to resection

questions.text: Which receptor is present in the marked region?

questions.text: A 48-year-old male was referred to the Oral Medicine Department for assessment of an asymptomatic white patch of 6 months duration on the right lateral border of his tongue. Extraoral examination of the head and neck was unremarkable with no evidence of lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the causative organism for your clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Oral hairy leukoplakia [OHL] is caused by EBV (Epstein Barr Virus).

Other viruses in the options above are not associated with the Oral hairy leukoplakia.

Option 1

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) Causes:

  • Congenital CMV Syndrome: hepatosplenomegaly, petechial lesions, chorio retinitis, calcification, microcephaly, mental Retardation.
  • Mononucleosis like syndrome: Atypical lymphocytes [CD8 T cells mainly] and PAUL Bunnel Test negative.
  • CMV Retinitis: CD4 count → <50 cells/mm3
Option 2

EBV (Epstein Barr Virus) causes:

  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Naso pharyngeal carcinoma
  • Burkitts lymphoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma / Non Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Tonsillar carcinoma
  • Duncan syndrome
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia. (Refer to the image below)
Option 3

Kaposi sarcoma : caused byHHV 8 (Human Herpes Virus)

  • common among HIV positive patients
  • vascular tumor
  • also associated with:
    • Primary effusion lymphoma
    • Castle man’s disease
Option 4

Varicella zoster : causeschicken pox in primary exposureand Herpes Zoster orShingles on reactivationof primary lesionin old age >60yrs.

Chicken pox:

  • Portal of entry → Respiratory tract / conjunctiva
  • centripetal Rash, DEW DROP APPEARANCE & Pleomorphism seen.

Herpes Zoster orShingles:

  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome
  • Herpes Zoster Opthalmicus

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the emergency room with an abrupt onset of high fever and difficulty swallowing. A single dose of IV Penicillin

questions.text: Angiographically, the typical appearance shown in image involving the internal carotid artery is observed in :
questions.solution:
Intra-arterial carotid angiography can be performed via a catheter placed in the aortic arch or by selective catheterization of the common carotid artery.

Irregularity due to atheroma must be differentiated from spasm (due to the presence of a catheter), fibromuscular dysplasia (extensive, regular, concentric corrugations of the artery producing “beaded or pile of plates” appearance, frequently bilateral and rarely extending above skull base), and from spontaneous or iatrogenic dissection (extensive narrowing, with some irregularity and slow flow, often extending up to the level of ophthalmic artery).

questions.text: The common causative factor for the following skin lesions is?
questions.solution:
Lesions are erythematous plaques with “target” appearance, diagnostic of Erythema multiforme.

Erythema multiforme :

  • A cutaneous reaction pattern with classic targetoid lesions that has many triggers and is often recurrent.
  • The disease can occur on mucous membranes, where erosions are seen.
  • Typically, lesions start as erythematous macules that become centrally clear and then develop a blister. The palms and soles are often affected.
  • A/w- fever, myalgias, headache, and arthralgias.
  • Diagnosed by clinical impression.
  • Rx- Symptomatic treatment is all that is necessary; systemic corticosteroids are of no benefit.
  • Minor cases can be treated with antipruritics; major cases should be treated as burns.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to his physician because of jaundice. He says that in the past few months he has not had much of an appetite and has lost 13.6 kg (30 lb). Physical examination is notable for a gallbladder that is palpable. What set of characteristics is expected in this patient?

choices.text: Type of hyperbilirubinemia – conjugated, Urine Bilirubin - ↑, Urine Urobilinogen - normal
Type of hyperbilirubinemia – conjugated, Urine Bilirubin - ↑, Urine Urobilinogen - ↓
Type of hyperbilirubinemia – unconjugated, Urine Bilirubin - ↑, Urine Urobilinogen - ↓
Type of hyperbilirubinemia – unconjugated, Urine Bilirubin - ↓, Urine Urobilinogen - ↑

questions.solution:
• The patient most likely has pancreatic adenocarcinoma that is located at the head of the pancreas, leading to obstruction of the common bile duct.
  • Weight loss, painless jaundice, and a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier Sign) can occur in pancreatic cancer.
  • The obstruction from the growing tumour results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with increased urine bilirubin levels and decreased urine urobilinogen levels

questions.text: A new born male baby was referred to the pediatric emergency with complaints of difficulty of breathing, incessant crying and barrel shaped chest. X-Ray done revealed a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. It is due to defect in which part of diaphragm?

A- SEPTUM TRANSVERSUM

B- PLEUROPERITONEALMEMBERANE

C- DORSAL MESENTRY OF ESOPHAGUS

D- MESODERM OF BODYWALL

  • The formation of the diaphragm occurs through the fusion of tissue from four different sources. The pleuroperitoneal membranes normally fuse with the three other components during week 6 of development.
  • Abnormal development or fusion of one or both of the pleuroperitoneal membranes causes a patent opening between the thorax and abdomen through which abdominal viscera may herniate

questions.text:
Arrange the following drugs according to their half-life in increasing order

Amiodarone
Adenosine
Esmolol
Omeprazole
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is the longest acting anti-arhythmic drug. Its half-life is more than 3 weeks.

Adenosine is the shortest acting anti-arrhythmic drug having a half-life of less than 10 seconds.

Esmolol is an ultra short-acting beta-blocker. It is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase and thus has a half-life of less than 5 minutes.

Omeprazole has a half-life of 1-2 hours but works for 24 hours due to irreversible inhibition of the proton pump.

Thus, the sequence is

Adenosine < Esmolol < Omeprazole < Amiodarone

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical signs of DVT had tachycardia and a history of bladder cancer. According to modified Well’s scoring, the probability of pulmonary embolism would be:
questions.solution:
Modified Wells criteria for predicting pumonary embolism(PE)
Variable Score
Clinical signs and symptoms DVT(minimum of leg swelling and pain on palpation of deep veins) 3
Alternative diagnosis less likely than PE 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization > 3 days or surgery within past 4 weeks 1..5
Previous DVT OR PE 1.5
Haemoptysis 1
Malignancy (including treatment within past 6 months ) 1
LOW RISK: <2
MODERATE RISK: 3-6
HIGH RISK: >6

questions.text: The partial pressure is a single gas component in a mixture of gases. It corresponds to the total pressure the single gas component would exert if it alone occupied the whole volume. At an altitude of 6500 meters, the atmospheric pressure is 347 mmHg. What is the inspired partial pressure of oxygen?
questions.solution:
Option B: 60 mmHg

  • According to the law of partial pressures :
    • The pressure exerted by a gas in a mixture is directly proportional to its concentration.
    • In inspired gases; 20 % = O2 , 78% = N2
    • PH2O = 47 mmHg (air humidified with inspiration)
    • = 347 – 47 = 300 mmHg = gaseous component

questions.text: A 25yrs old, male patient with a family history of Diabetes Mellitus for 2 successive generations. He is not having any classical symptoms of DM. questions.solution:

  • Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults is a variant of type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • MODY has impaired glucose induced insulin release due to autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. The beta cell mass is normal. It involves mutations in nuclear transcription factor that regulates islet gene expression.
  • Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition neurodegenerative disorder leading to diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, optic atrophy and deafness.
  • MODY is associated with
    • Young age
    • Non-insulin dependent diabetes
    • Positive family historyin 2successive generations
    • Radio Immune Assay of Insulin is normal/low

questions.text: A patient was given 600 mg of a drug intravenously out of which 300 mg was eliminated in 180 minutes. If the drug follows first-order elimination kinetics, how much of the drug will remain 12 hours after its administration?
questions.solution:
The T1/2 of the above drug is 3 hours.(As half of the total dose(300mg) is eliminated in 3 hours). 12 hours is 4 T1/2.

In first-order kinetics Fraction remains constant with each T1/2.

Therefore 50% of 600 is 300 mg= 1st T1/2, Second T1/2=150 mg, Third T1/2=75mg, Fourth T1/2=37.5 mg.

Order of kinetics:

FIRST-ORDER ZERO-ORDER
Constant fraction of drug is eliminated The constant amount is eliminated
The rate of elimination is directly proportional to plasma concentration The rate of elimination is constant
Clearance is constant Clearance is inversely proportional to plasma concentration
Half-life is constant Half-life is directly proportional to plasma concentration.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child is brought to his paediatrician’s office for a check-up. On examination, the physician notices that he has a social smile, but does not hold his head up, on his own or make noises. The infant also has pale skin, eczema, odd odour, and hyperreflexia. What is the most appropriate treatment for the condition the infant most likely has?

choices.text: A diet low in isoleucine and leucine

questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria: Phenyl ketonei.e. Phenyl Pyruvate found in urine of these patients (Pyruvate is a Keto-acid).

Affected children are normal at birth but fail to reach developmental milestones

Clinical features:

Body odour – mousy or musty because of phenylacetate.

Severe mental retardation due to excess Phenylalanine.

Tyrosine becomes essential

Deficiency of pigment Melanin (formed from Tyrosine), leads to fair skin, blue eyes and light hair colour.

OTHER FEATURES: Microcephaly, rash, hypertonia, seizures, hyperactivity, exaggerated tendon reflexes, wide-spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia.

Rx:-

Decreased dietary phenylalanine (which is contained in many foods, including artificial sweeteners).

Dietary tyrosine supplementation (In patients with PKU, tyrosine cannot be derived from phenylalanine)

Currently, screening is mandatory and performed 6 days to 2 weeks after birth using high-performance liquid chromatography.

questions.text: A hypothetical 28-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of erectile dysfunction for about 1 y. He reports that sexual desire is present but that he has a lack of ability to achieve and maintain an erection. He also says that he has avoided physical affection with his wife in order to avoid the embarrassment of ‘not being able to perform.’ The test/procedure that you can do in this patient to know whether his condition is psychological or organic is:
questions.solution:
• The presence of early morning erections and erections during REM sleep (nocturnal erections) is suggestive of psychogenic erectile dysfunction.
  • As during sleep, there is no anxiety, hence a patient with psychogenic erectile dysfunction is able to have erections.
  • Whereas, a patient with organic erectile dysfunction (due to vascular or neurological causes) won’t have erections even during sleep.
  • Investigation such as penile plethysmography and nocturnal penile intumescence (NPT) can be used to record nocturnal erections

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about FLAIR MRI
1. FLAIR stands for Fluid Attenuation Induction and Recovery.
2. It can be used with both three-dimensional imaging (3D FLAIR) and two-dimensional imaging (2D FLAIR)
3. CSF appears bright on T2-FLAIR
4. It negates the fluid signals.
5. T2 images are more sensitive for detecting demyelination, infarction, and chronic hemorrhage.
questions.solution:
• T2-FLAIR stands for T2-weighted-Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery.
  • Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is a pulse sequence used in magnetic resonance imaging which was invented by Dr. Graeme Bydder.
  • FLAIR can be used with both three-dimensional imaging (3D FLAIR) and two dimensional imaging (2D FLAIR). The pulse sequence is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluids.
  • Structures with more water such as CSF or edema have long T1 and T2 relaxation times, resulting in higher signal intensity on T2-weighted images.
  • T2 images are also more sensitive for detecting demyelination, infarction, and chronic hemorrhage.
  • Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is a type of T2- weighted image that suppresses the high-intensity signal of CSF. As a result, images created by the FLAIR technique are more sensitive to detecting water- containing things/lesions.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to ENT OPD with complaints of recurrent respiratory tract infection. The mother complains about this recurrent infection, mouth breathing and decreased hearing. The tympanic membrane appears bluish in color with the absence of light reflex. Which of the following is the best treatment modality:
questions.solution:
Above is a presentation of the Glue ear, Adenoidectomy with Grommet insertion is the treatment of choice

SEROUS OTITIS MEDIA (Non-suppurative Otitis media/Glue Ear/Secretory Otitis Media/Serous Otitis media/Mucoid Otitis media):

An insidious condition characterized by accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft.

Since there is No infection/Pus Accumulation, it is called Sterile Effusion, although bacteria have been discovered by PCR analysis

Eustachian tube fails to aerate the middle ear and is also unable to drain the fluid resulting in a collection of effusion

The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex. It may appear yellow, grey, or bluish in color.

A thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along with the handle of the malleus or at the periphery of the tympanic membrane and differs from marked congestion of acute suppurative otitis media.

Tympanic membrane may show varying degrees of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.

Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.

The mobility of the tympanic membrane is Restricted.

Serous otitis media is a sterile collection in the middle ear and not infective because of respiratory condition.

questions.text: All the following characteristic patterns are seen in Brown Sequard syndrome, except?

questions.text: A microbiology assistant wants to sterilize heat sensitive vaccines. Which of the following is best to sterilize heat labile solutions?
questions.solution:
Heat sensitive liquids like serum, vaccines, antisera, enzymes, antibiotic solutions and urea solutions can be sterilized by usingmembrane filtration.The filtration can be aided by using either positive or negative pressure.

2 TYPES OF FILTERS:

1. DEPTH FILTERS– POROUS FILTERS [metal polymer with random mats]

Examples:

  • candle Filters
  • unglazed porcelain Filters
  • Seitz Filter
  • Sintered glass filter

2. MEMBRANE FILTERS

  • most widely used filters For bacterial Filtration
  • made up of cellulose acetate, cellulose nitrate, polycarbonate
  • pore size:
    • 0.22 µ → most common used
    • 0.45 µ → retains coliforms
    • 0.8 µ → retains airbone micro organisms

USE→ to sterilize sugar, sera & antibiotic solutions

AIR FILTERS:

  1. HEPA[High efficiency particulate air] FILTER→ Removes 99.97% of particles having a size 0.3µ or more.
  2. ULPA[Ultra Low Particulate/Penetration]→ Removes 99.999% of dust, pollen, molds.

CONTROL → Brevundimonasdiminuta& Serratia marcesens

questions.text: Which one of the following does NOT primarily involve an action via K+ channels?

choices.text: Carotid body discharge with reduced O2
Dantrolene in the treatment of Malignant Hyperthermia

questions.solution:
• Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and carotid body discharge are brought about by the O2-sensitive K+ channel.
  • Insulin secretion by sulfonylurea is brought about by its action via the ATP-sensitive K+ channel on the pancreatic B-cell.
  • Malignant hyperthermia is a disorder of excitation-contraction coupling, resulting from a genetic defect of RyR (a Ca++-release channel). Dantrolene uncouples the excitation from contraction, by acting on the Ca++ channel.

As domperidone does not cross BBB, it blocks levodopa-induced vomiting without blocking its anti - parkinsonism effect.
