questions.text:
Read the following statements about Glycogen storage disorders:

Type IV is due to Branching enzyme deficiency, which leads to progressive cirrhosis of the liver.
Type I is due to alpha 1-4 glucosidase enzyme deficiency and it leads to severe hypoglycemia and massive enlargement of the liver.
Type V is due to glycogen phosphorylase deficiency and leads to painful muscle cramps.
Type II is due to alpha 1-4 deficiency and it is associated with Cardiomyopathy.
Type III is due to Branching enzyme deficiency and it leads to milder hypoglycemia

Identify the wrong statements:
questions.solution:
Glycogen storage disorders:

type name Enzyme deficiency Organ Clinical features
I Von Gierke's disease Glucose 6-phosphatase Liver, kidney, git
  • Glycogen accumulation in liver and kidney
  • Hypoglycemia lactic acidemiaketosis· hyperlipidemia
II Pompe's disease Lysosomal alpha-1,4 glucosidase (acid maltase) All organs
  • Glycogen accumulation in lysosome in all organ
  • The heart is mostly affected
  • Death occurs at an early age due to heart failure
III Cori's disease/ Limit Dextrinosis Amylo alpha-1,6-glucosidase (debranching enzyme) Liver muscles and heart
  • fasting hypoglycemia
  • hepatomegaly in infancy
  • accumulation of characteristics branched polysaccharides (limit dextrin)
  • muscles weakness
IV Anderson's disease/ Amylopectinosis Glucosyl 4-6 transferase(branching enzyme) Most tissue
  • A rare disease, glycogen with only a few branches accumulate; cirrhosis of the liver
  • Death before 5 years of age due to heart failure or liver failure
V McArdle's disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Skeletal tissue
  • Muscles glycogen is very high but it cannot be used during exercise.
  • Cannot perform strenuous exercise
  • Muscles cramps
  • Blood lactate and pyruvate do not increase after exercise
VI Her's disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Liver
  • The liver is increased in size because liver glycogen cannot convert into glucose
  • Mild hypoglycemia and ketosis
  • Good prognosis
VII Tarui's disease Phosphofructokinase Skeletal muscles and RBC
  • Muscles cramps due to exercise
  • Blood lactate is elevated
  • Hemolysis occurs

questions.text: A 30-year female presented with mucosal bleeds on trauma and also has history of menorrhagia. BT and partial prothrombin time are elevated. Ristocetin assay is positive. The use of desmopressin is best indicated in this disease. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Patients with Von Willebrand disease facing hemostatic challenges (dental work, surgery, etc.) can be treated with desmopressin, which stimulates vWF release, or with infusions of plasma concentrates containing factor VIII and vWF.
  • Hemophilia A and B (severe phenotype) are treated by deficient factor replacement therapy, fresh frozen plasma, etc.
  • Desmopressin can be used in the treatment of mild hemophilia A.
  • Platelet transfusion is the standard treatment for severe bleeding and perioperative hemostasis in patients with Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

questions.text: A competitive neuromuscular blockage which acts on nicotinic receptor was given to a patient. Which of the following drug can be administered to reverse the effects of that drug?
questions.solution:
• Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors are used clinically to antagonize the residual effect of neuromuscular blockers and to accelerate recovery from non- depolarizing neuromuscular blockade.
  • The acetylcholine that accumulate at the neuromuscular junction following the administration of neostigmine competes with the residual molecules of the neuromuscular blocking drug for the available unoccupied nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the junction.

questions.text: A scientist working in a research laboratory has been examining different agonists of serotonin receptor 1B (5-HT1B), a G-protein-coupled receptor. Compound A has a much higher affinity for 5-HT1B than compound B. Both compounds have a higher affinity for the receptor than serotonin. Which of the following describes the relationship between compound A and compound B when considering the guanine-nucleotide exchange activity of 5-HT1B?

choices.text: Km for the exchange reaction with compound A is higher than that with compound B
Km values with compounds A and B are the same
Km for the exchange reaction with compound A is lower than that with compound B
The maximum reaction rate with compound A is greater than that with compound B

questions.solution:
G-protein coupled receptors exist in an equilibrium between their active and inactive states that is dependent on whether ligand is present, and the affinity of the ligand for the receptor. When active, these receptors catalyze guanine-nucleotide exchange (GTP for guanosine diphosphate) of their associated G proteins.

The Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) for any enzyme-catalyzed reaction is inversely proportional to the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate. Therefore, the Km for compound A will be lower than that for compound B because compound A has a higher affinity for the receptor than compound B.

The maximum rate of reaction (Vmax) will be reached at a lower concentration of A than it would for B, although the Vmax is unchanged.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female who underwent parotidectomy on right side 1 month back came with complaints of flushing, sweating and burning sensation on the right side of her face whenever she eats. Which postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibre is responsible for the symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Auriculotemporal nervecarries parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to parotid gland.
  • After parotidectomy, sometimes there may be a regeneration of secretomotor fibres in Auriculotemporal Nerve
  • This regeneration ismisdirectedinto sweat glands. Thus, whenever the patient thinks of food/smells /chews food there would be stimulation of sweat glands &hyperaemia resulting in redness & sweating in front of the ear on cheek.
  • This is also seen with injury to the parotid gland during other procedures, as quoted in this case scenario.
  • This clinical entity is called ‘FREY SYNDROME’/AURICULOTEMPORAL SYNDROME/GUSTATORY SWEATING.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, Vishnu presents with pulmonary lesions seen on chest CT scan. He has a history of melanoma which was treated with wide local excision with negative margins and lymph node dissection. Biopsy of these pulmonary lesions proves to be metastatic melanoma. The general condition of the patient is good & there is no evidence of recurrence or extrathoracic disease. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Pulmonary metastasectomy followed by radiation therapy

questions.solution:
• This is likely a case of metastasis from the earlier removed malignant melanoma.
  • Since the primary lesion is excised & there is no evidence of extrathoracic disease and patient’s general condition is good, the appropriate treatment is pulmonary metastasectomy.
  • There is no role for radiation therapy pre or postoperatively for melanoma.
  • Pulmonary metastasectomy can be performed for sarcomas, melanomas, germ cell tumors, and carcinomas of colon, renal cell and head and neck

questions.text: A child presents with a history of irritability, developmental delay, and urine with burnt sugar odor to a Pediatrics OPD. Excess of all of the amino acids can be tested in the urine of this child EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
MAPLE Syrup urine disease: This defect occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in a defect in Oxidative phosphorylation and Catabolism of Branch chain amino acid -Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in the urine.

Clinical Features

  • Autosomal Recessive
  • Burnt sugar like odour (because of isoleucine)
  • Ketosis, vomiting, feeding problems
  • Mental retardation (because of increased leucine)
  • Abnormal muscle tone
  • If not treated, then coma (because of increased leucine )
  • Death can occur (high mortality rate )

There are 4 known types of Maple Syrup Urine Disease:

  • Type IA and IB MSUD arise from mutations in the E1α and E1b genes, which encode the enzyme α-Ketoacid decarboxylase.
  • Type II arises from mutations in the E2 gene, which encodes Dihydrolipoyltransacylase.
  • Type III arises from mutations in the E3 gene, which encodes Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant has the following vascular lesion on her left cheek. The parents state it was not present at birth but had been growing rapidly for the first few weeks of life. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Superficial infantile hemangioma

  • Infantile or strawberry hemangioma is a benign capillary vascular tumor of infancy (mostly girls), which occurs in 3–10% of infants.
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal development of vascular endothelial cells.
  • Prognosis: Rapid proliferation followed by subsequent spontaneous slow involution (occurring at the age of 5–8 years).
  • Complications include ulceration and disfigurement.
  • Visual impairment if the periorbital hemangioma is left untreated.

Option B: Milia neonatorum

  • Milia neonatorum is tiny epidermal papules caused by the buildup of keratin and sebaceous secretions.
  • Clinical features: pinhead-sized lesions located on the face/trunk
  • Treatment: not necessary

Option C: Deep infantile hemangioma

  • A deep infantile hemangioma can be compressed and quickly regain its original dimensions on the release of pressure.
  • It becomes larger and darker when the child screams or cries.
  • Virtually 100% of infantile haemangiomas undergo spontaneous regression, which is complete or almost complete in about 95%.

Option D: Pyogenic granuloma

Pyogenic granulomas are benign vascular tumors characterized by rapid growth and a tendency to bleed easily.

  • It is associated with trauma and pregnancy.
  • A soft, round, bright red tumor that bleeds easily.
  • Localization: usually develops at the site of skin injury on the face or hands.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, third-ranked sumo wrestler (height, 185 cm; weight, 150 kg). He twisted his left foot during sumo training and felt pain. 5th metatarsal is the M/C metatarsal to undergo traumatic fracture. Base of 5th metatarsal is divided into three zones-· Zone 1. Avulsion fractures (Pseudo Jones fracture/ dancer’s fracture) of peroneus brevis(not longus) tendon.Zone 2. Fractures at the metaphysealdiaphyseal junction (Jone’s fracture)Zone 3. Stress fractures of the proximal 1.5 cm of the shaft of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male athlete who is practicing for his upcoming marathon felt chest discomfort during his practice which was relieved after few minutes of rest. Which of the following is false regarding the cell injury in this scenario?

choices.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum
Accumulation of myelin figures in the cytoplasm

questions.solution:
• On microscopic examination of reversibly injured cells, small clear vacuoles may be seen within the cytoplasm; these represent distended and pinched-off segments of the ER.
  • This pattern of nonlethal injury is sometimes called hydropic change or vacuolar degeneration.
  • The ultrastructural changes of reversible cell injury, visible by electron microscopy include the following:
  • Plasma membrane alterations, such as blebbing, blunting, and loss of microvilli
  • Mitochondrial changes, including swelling and the appearance of small amorphous densities
  • Accumulation of “myelin figures” in the cytosol composed of phospholipids derived from damaged cellular membranes
  • Dilation of the ER, with detachment of polysomes
  • Nuclear alterations, with disaggregation of granular and fibrillar elements
  • Phenomena that consistently characterize irreversible cell injury:
    • inability to reverse mitochondrial dysfunction (lack of oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation) even after resolution of the original injury
    • profound disturbances in membrane function (breakdown of plasma membrane).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the reproductive cycle of women is correct?

Inhibin B gives negative feedback to FSH in follicular phase
Progesterone gives negative feedback to LH in luteal phase
Estrone is responsible for proliferative phase
Estradiol is the product of aromatization
questions.solution:
• Estrone is the product of aromatization.
  • LH acts on adipose cells to convert androgens to Estrone with the help ofaromatase enzyme known as aromatization
  • Estradiol produced by ovarian granulosa cells is responsible for the LHpeak to happen and subsequent ovulation
  • Inhibin B and Estradiol gives negative feedback to FSH in follicular phasein which Inhibin is predominant
  • Progesterone once it reaches >6ng/ml that is mostly on the 8th day of ovulation, gives negative feedback to LH to decrease it support forcorpus luteum.
  • Subsequently, the corpus luteum degenerates and the progesterone hormone declines

questions.text: Young female comes in with primary amenorrhea with normal breast, normal pubic hair. USG reveals absent uterus and cervix with short vaginal pouch and ovaries. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mullerian agenesis:

  • Congenital absence of both uterus and vagina is referred as Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • In classic Mullerian agenesis, patients have a shallow vaginal pouch. In addition, the uterus, cervix and upper part of the vagina are absent.
  • Typically, a portion of the distal fallopian tubes are present. In addition, normal ovaries are present, given their separate embryonic origin.
  • Most patients with Mullerian agenesis have only small rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without endometrial activity
  • Surgical excision of symptomatic rudimentary bulbs is required. With Mullerian agenesis, traditional conception is impossible, but pregnancy may be achieved using sophisticated technology involving oocyte retrieval, fertilization and implantation into a surrogate.

questions.text: This segment of the arterial intima of a coronary vessel is observed at autopsy in a 56-year old man who died suddenly on rising in the morning. Which of the following abnormalities is considered a major risk factor for the development of this lesion?
questions.solution:
• The figure shows an organized atheromatous plaque occluding the vascular lumen.
  • The slit-like spaces in the middle are cholesterol clefts surrounded by fibroblasts.
  • The clinical scenario strongly suggests that this affected vessel is a coronary artery.
  • Cleft-like spaces indicating the presence of cholesterol crystals are very prominent and help in the identification of the lesion.
  • The incidence of atherosclerosis is strongly associated with hypercholesterolemia.
  • Principal components of atheromatous plaque:
    • Smooth muscle cells, macrophages, and T cells.
    • Matrix, including collagen, elastic fiber, and proteoglycans
    • Intracellular and extracellular lipid.
    • Calcification in later stages

questions.text: A 40 year old male visited to the hospital for permanent sterilization operation. The physician explained him about vasectomy method. Which of the following is not true regarding ‘no scalpel’ vasectomy?

choices.text: Special instruments are used to deliver the vas instead of cutting the skin
Scrotal skin is cut with LASER to expose the vas
The failure rate is same as that of conventional vasectomy
It is a very popular method in China

questions.solution:
• No scalpel vasectomy(also called keyholevasectomyor NSV) is avasectomy procedurevariant in which a sharp hemostat is used to puncture the scrotum to access the vas deferens instead of giving an incision as in conventionalvasectomy.
  • No cuts are made in no-scalpel vasectomy, but the skin is punctured.
  • The failure rate is same as that of conventional vasectomy.
  • It is a very popular method in China
